page.title: Attacks by Islamic extremists in Bangladesh

revision.text:
{{pp-move-dispute|small=yes}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}}
'''Attacks by Islamic extremists in Bangladesh''' refers to increased attacks since 2013 on a number of [[secularist]] and [[atheist]] writers, bloggers, and publishers in [[Bangladesh]] and foreigners, and religious minorities such as [[Hindu]]s, [[Buddhist]]s, [[Christian]]s, and [[Shia Islam|Shias]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6">{{cite news |date=7 August 2015 |title=Fourth secular Bangladesh blogger hacked to death|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/08/fourth-secular-bangladesh-blogger-hacked-death-150807102408712.html |work=aljazeera.com}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/motion-timeline-29-militant-killings-4-years-1217401 |title=Motion Timeline: 29 killings in 4 years |journal=thedailystar.net |date=2 May 2016 |accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> These attacks have been largely blamed on extremist groups such as [[Ansarullah Bangla Team]] and [[Islamic State of Iraq and Syria]].<ref name=":6" />
The Bangladeshi government was criticized for its responses to the attacks, which included charging and jailing some of the secularist bloggers for allegedly defaming religious groups{{snd}}a strategy seen as pandering to hard line elements within Bangladesh's majority Muslim population (about 89% of the population). The government's eventual crackdown in June 2016 was also criticized for its heavy-handedness, as more than 11,000 people were arrested in little more than a week (as of 18{{nbsp}}June 2016).<ref>{{citation |title=Round up the usual suspects: A spate of assassinations provokes a heavy-handed response |journal=The Economist |url=https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21700669-spate-assassinations-provokes-heavy-handed-response-round-up-usual-suspects |date=18 June 2016}}</ref>
As of 2 July 2016, a total of 48 people, including 20 foreign nationals, were killed in such attacks.
== Background == In 2010 the government of Bangladesh, headed by the secularist [[Awami League]], established a [[International Crimes Tribunal (Bangladesh)|war crimes tribunal]] to investigate war crimes perpetrated during Bangladesh{{'s}} bloody 1971 [[Bangladesh Liberation War|War of Independence]] from [[Pakistan]]. In February 2013 [[Abdul Quader Molla]], a leader of the [[Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami]] party (a small Islamist party within the opposition coalition), was sentenced to life imprisonment by the tribunal. The sentence was condemned by Bangladesh's secularist bloggers and writers, who helped organize the [[2013 Shahbag protests]] in response, calling for the death penalty for Molla. The protestors quickly expanded their demands to include outlawing the Jamaat-e-Islami party itself for its role in the 1971 war.<ref name=nyt_3mar2013>{{cite news |author1=Julfikar Ali Manik |author2=Jim Yardley |date= 3 March 2013 |title= At Least 19 Killed as Unrest Persists in Bangladesh |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/04/world/asia/bangladesh-sees-deadly-day-as-protests-persist.html |newspaper= The New York Times |access-date= 29 May 2015 }}</ref>
Shortly after the first [[Shahbag]] protests, counter-demonstrations, which quickly degenerated into violence, were organized by Islamist groups. Islamist leaders denounced the war crimes tribunal as political and called for an end to the prosecution of Jamaat-e-Islami leaders;<ref name=nyt_3mar2013/> they demanded instead the death penalty for secularist bloggers, denouncing them as "atheists" and accusing them of [[blasphemy]].<ref name=heroes_mohiuddin>{{cite web |url= http://heroes.rsf.org/en/asif-mohiuddin/ |title= 100 Information Heroes: Asif Mohiuddin |website= Reporters Without Borders |access-date= 29 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508130737/http://heroes.rsf.org/en/asif-mohiuddin/ |archive-date=8 May 2014}}</ref><ref name=usatoday_6apr2013>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/04/06/hardline-muslims-rally-bangladesh/2058851/|title=Hardline Muslims rally in Bangladesh amid shutdown|date=6 April 2013|work=USA Today|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> A spokesman for the secularist bloggers, [[Imran H Sarker|Imran Sarker]], stated that the hostility directed toward them by Islamists is due primarily to the bloggers' growing political influence in Bangladesh, which represents a major obstacle to the Islamist goal of a religious state.<ref name=dw_30mar2015>{{cite news |last1=Chowdhury |first1=Arun |last2=Shams |first2=Shamil |date=30 March 2015 |title=Bangladeshi bloggers pay the price of upholding secularism |url=http://www.dw.de/bangladeshi-bloggers-pay-the-price-of-upholding-secularism/a-18349725 |work=Deutsche Welle |access-date = 16 May 2015}}</ref>
Though there were occasional attacks on secularists prior to the 2013 Shahbag protests, the frequency of attacks has increased since. [[Reporters Without Borders]] noted that in 2014 a group calling itself "Defenders of Islam" published a "hit list" of 84 Bangladeshis, mostly secularists, of whom nine have already reportedly been killed and others attacked.<ref name=cnn_13may2015>{{cite news |last1=Ahmed |first1=Saeed |date=13 May 2015 |title=Ananta Bijoy Das: Yet another Bangladeshi blogger hacked to death |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/05/12/asia/bangladesh-blogger-killed/ |work=[[CNN]] |access-date=12 May 2015}}</ref> Responsibility for many of the attacks has been claimed by [[Ansarullah Bangla Team]],<ref name="4-arrested-attempted-murder">{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/4-held-over-attempt-to-kill-blogger/|title=4 held over attempt to kill blogger|work=The Daily Star|publisher=Transcom Group|date=2 April 2013|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ansar Bangla-7 claims Avijit killing responsibility|url=http://en.prothom-alo.com/bangladesh/news/59777/Ansar-Bangla-7-claims-Avijit-killing|work=Prothom Alo|publisher=Transcom Group|date=27 February 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/secular-blogger-hacked-to-death-in-bangladesh-month-after-almost-identical-murder-of-idol-10143498.html|author=Lizzie Dearden|title=An atheist blogger has been hacked to death in Bangladesh for the second time this year|work=The Independent|publisher=Independent Digital News and Media|date=30 March 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=bdnews24_16nov2014>{{cite news |date=16 November 2014 |title=Islamist group claim responsibility of RU teacher murder |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2014/11/16/islamist-group-claim-responsibility-of-ru-teacher-murder |newspaper=bdnews24.com |access-date=16 May 2015}}</ref> a group that, according to police, has links with both the youth wing of Jamaat-e-Islami and [[al-Qaeda]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Blogger Rajib’s ‘killers’ linked to al-Qaeda: DB|work=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]]|publisher=Transcom Group|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/blogger-rajibs-killers-linked-to-al-qaeda-db/|date=15 March 2013|access-date=2 June 2015}}</ref> The group has since been banned by the government.<ref>{{cite news |date=25 May 2015|title=Bangladesh bans Islamist group accused of blogger attacks |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32879662 |work=BBC News}}</ref> Other attacks appear to have been perpetrated by more obscure groups. Among some extremists, this violence is motivated by [[inceldom]].<ref>https://www.dhakatribune.com/opinion/op-ed/2018/05/07/incel-rebellion-already-begun/</ref>
== Government and international response == While police have arrested a number of suspects in the killings, and some bloggers have received police protection, the Bangladesh government has also responded by arresting and jailing a number of secularist bloggers for "defaming Islam" and by shutting down several websites.<ref name=guardian_28feb2015>{{cite news |date=27 February 2015 |title=American atheist blogger hacked to death in Bangladesh |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/27/american-atheist-blogger-hacked-to-death-in-bangladesh |work=[[The Guardian]] |agency=Agence France-Presse |access-date=27 February 2015 }}</ref> According to Sarker, "[T]he government has taken this easy route to appease a handful of mullahs whose support they need to win the upcoming election."<ref name=iheu_4apr2013>{{cite web |url= http://iheu.org/arrests-atheist-bloggers-shows-bangladesh-authorities-are-walking-trap-set-fundamentalists/ |title= Arrests of 'atheist bloggers' shows Bangladesh authorities are "walking into a trap set by fundamentalists" |author=<!-- Staff writer(s); no by-line. --> |date= 4 April 2013 |website= International Humanist and Ethical Union |access-date= 2 June 2015 }}</ref>
A number of non-governmental organisations ([[NGO]]s), including [[Human Rights Watch]], [[Amnesty International]], [[Reporters without Borders]], [[PEN International]], [[PEN Canada]] and the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] have criticized the government for failing to protect its citizens and for not condemning the attacks,<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.amnesty.ca/news/bangladesh-authorities-must-act-another-secular-activist-hacked-death |title=Bangladesh: Authorities must act as another secular activist hacked to death |date=April 7, 2016 |publisher=Amnesty International}}</ref> and have condemned the imprisonment of bloggers as an attack on free speech, which they say is contributing to a climate of fear for Bangladeshi journalists.<ref>{{cite news | title =Bangladesh: Crackdown on Bloggers, Editors Escalates | publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]]|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/04/15/bangladesh-crackdown-bloggers-editors-escalates| date = 15 April 2013}} "[T]he government is abandoning any serious claim that it is committed to free speech," said Brad Adams, Asia director at Human Rights Watch."</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/ASA13/007/2013/en/|title=Bangladesh: Further information: Detained editor alleges torture|quote=Blogger Asif Mohiudeen, arrested on 3 April for allegedly posting blasphemous comments online, remains in detention and at risk of torture|publisher=Amnesty International|date=17 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rsf.org/bangladesh-call-for-detained-blogger-s-11-04-2013,44367.html |title=Call for detained blogger's immediate release|publisher=Reporters without Borders|date=11 April 2013 |quote=Reporters Without Borders condemns the baseless judicial proceedings brought against the detained blogger Asif Mohiuddin, who could be tried and convicted on a charge of blasphemy and "hurting religious sentiments" at his next hearing.}}</ref><ref name="cpj2013">{{cite web|url=https://www.cpj.org/2014/02/attacks-on-the-press-in-2013-bangladesh.php|title=Attacks on the Press – Bangladesh|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=Feb 2014}}</ref>
In a petition published in ''[[The Guardian]]'' on 22{{nbsp}}May 2015, 150 authors, including [[Salman Rushdie]], [[Margaret Atwood]], and [[Yann Martell]], called on the government of Bangladesh to put an end to the deadly attacks on bloggers, urging the Prime Minister and government "to do all in their power to ensure that the tragic events of the last three months are not repeated, and to bring the perpetrators to justice."<ref name=":3">{{cite news |date=22 May 2015 |title=Top authors including Salam Rushdie urge Bangladesh govt to halt blogger attacks |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/world/top-authors-urge-bangladesh-govt-halt-blogger-attacks-85669 |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |access-date = 22 May 2015}}</ref>
On 7 June 2016 Bangladeshi Home Minister Asaduzzaman Khan alleged that the main opposition party [[Bangladesh Nationalist Party|BNP]] has links to the attacks, and that these attacks are part of a wider conspiracy that also involved [[Mossad]], the national intelligence agency of [[Israel]].<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/bangladeshi-minister-blames-israel-for-string-of-gruesome-murders/|title=Bangladeshi minister blames Israel for string of gruesome murders|website=[[The Times of Israel]]|access-date=2016-06-16}}</ref> An Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman in Jerusalem later rejected the allegation in a statement and termed the accusation of the Bangladeshi Home Minister as "utter drivel".<ref name=":12" />
The [[United Nations]] High Commissioner for Human Rights, [[Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein]], expressed concern on behalf of the United Nations on 13{{nbsp}}June 2016 by saying, "I am very concerned about the dramatic increase in number{{sic}} of brutal murders in Bangladesh that target freethinkers, liberals, religious minorities and LGBT activists."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/un-concerned-over-bangladesh-killings-1238938|title=UN concerned over Bangladesh killings|date=2016-06-13|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref>
On 14 June 2016 approximately 100,000 Bangladeshi Muslim clerics released a [[fatwa]], ruling that the murder of "non-Muslims, minorities and secular activists…forbidden in Islam".<ref>{{cite news|title=Mass arrests in Bangladesh|url=https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21700669-spate-assassinations-provokes-heavy-handed-response-round-up-usual-suspects|accessdate=20 June 2016|work=[[The Economist]]|date=18 June 2016}}</ref>
== Attacks on secularists ==
=== Asif Mohiuddin === On 15 January 2013 [[Asif Mohiuddin]], a self-described "militant atheist" blogger,<ref name=ht_15jan2013>{{cite news |date=15 January 2013 |title='Militant atheist' blogger stabbed in Bangladesh |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/militant-atheist-blogger-stabbed-in-bangladesh/article1-989966.aspx |newspaper=[[The Hindustan Times]] |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |access-date = 27 January 2014}}</ref> was stabbed near his office in [[Motijheel]], [[Dhaka]]. He survived the attack.<ref name=ht_15jan2013/> Mohiuddin, a winner of the [[The BOBs (weblog award)|BOBs award]] for online activism, was on an Islamist hit list that also included the sociology professor Shafiul Islam.<ref name="en.rsf.org">{{cite web |url=http://en.rsf.org/bangladesh-bloggers-on-hit-list-posted-by-19-11-2014,47250.html |title=Bloggers on hit-list posted by supposed Islamist group in Bangladesh |date=19 November 2014 |website=Reporters Without Borders}}</ref> The Islamist fundamentalist group Ansarullah Bangla Team claimed responsibility for the attack. According to Mohiuddin, he later met his attackers in jail, and they told him, "You left Islam, you are not a Muslim, you criticized the Koran, we had to do this."<ref name=dw_22apr2014>{{cite news |last1=King |first1=Neil |last2=Early |first2=Samantha |date=22 April 2014 |title='I have to help the people of Bangladesh' |url=http://www.dw.de/i-have-to-help-the-people-of-bangladesh/a-17581354 |work= Deutsche Welle |access-date=11 May 2015}}</ref> Reporters Without Borders stated that Mohiuddin and others have "clearly" been targeted for their "opposition to religious extremism".<ref name="en.rsf.org"/>
=== Ahmed Rajib Haider === On the night of 15 February 2013, [[Ahmed Rajib Haider]], an atheist blogger, was attacked while leaving his house in the Mirpur neighborhood of Dhaka. His body was found lying in a pool of blood,<ref name=bdnews24_16feb2013> {{cite news | title = Killers hacked Rajib first, then slit his throat: police | publisher = [[bdnews24.com]] | url = http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/02/16/killers-hacked-rajib-first-then-slit-his-throat-police | date = 16 February 2013 }}</ref> mutilated to the point that his friends could not recognise him.<ref name=ct> {{cite news | title = Islamist agitation fuels unrest in Bangladesh | author = John Chalmers | work = [[Chicago Tribune]] | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-04-15/news/sns-rt-us-bangladesh-politicsbre93e158-20130415_1_islamist-shahbag-rajib-haider | date = 15 April 2013 }}</ref> The following day, his coffin was carried through [[Shahbagh Square]] in a public protest attended by more than [[2013 Shahbag protests|100,000 people]].<ref name=nyt_16feb2013> {{cite news | title = Vast Throng in Bangladesh Protests Killing of Activist | author = [[Jim Yardley]] | work = [[The New York Times]] | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/17/world/asia/vast-throng-in-bangladesh-protests-killing-of-activist.html | date = 16 February 2013 }}</ref>
Haider was an organizer of the Shahbag movement,<ref name=bdnews24_16feb2013/> a group "which seeks death for war criminals and a ban on Jamaat-e-Islami and its student front [[Bangladesh Islami Chhatra Shibir|Islami Chhatra Shibir]]."<ref name=conf/> According to Haider's family, Haider was murdered "for the blogs he used to write to bring 'war criminals' to justice"<ref name=conf/> and for his outspoken criticism of the Jamaat-e-Islami party.<ref name=nyt_16feb2013/> The Shahbag movement described Haider as their "first martyr".<ref name=conf/>
=== Sunnyur Rahaman === On the night of 7 March 2013 Sunnyur Rahaman was injured when two men swooped in on him and hacked him with machetes. He came under attack around 9:00 p.m. near the Purabi Cinema Hall in Mirpur, Dhaka. With the assistance of local police, he was rushed to [[Dhaka Medical College and Hospital]] with wounds to his head, neck, right leg, and left hand.<ref>{{cite news |date=8 March 2013 |title=Youth hacked injured at Mirpur |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/youth-hacked-injured-at-mirpur/ |newspaper=The Daily Star |access-date=20 April 2015}}</ref> Rahaman was a [[2013 Shahbag protests|Shahbag movement]] activist and a critic of various religious parties, including Jamaat-e-Islami.<ref name=bdnews24_7mar2013>{{cite news |author=<!-- Staff writer(s); no by-line. --> |title= Another blogger stabbed at Pallabi |url= http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/03/07/another-blogger-stabbed-at-pallabi |newspaper= bdnews24 |location= Bangladesh |date= 7 March 2013 |access-date= 2 May 2015 }}</ref>
=== Shafiul Islam === On 15 November 2014 a teacher in the [[Rajshahi University]] sociology department named Shafiul Islam, a follower of the [[Bauls|Baul community]], was struck with sharp weapons by several youths on his way home in Rajshahi city.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.secularhumanism.org/index.php/articles/7551|title=Crisis in Bangladesh: Secularists Killed by Extremists and Under Legal Threat from Government|website=www.secularhumanism.org}}</ref> He died after being taken to Rajshahi Medical College and Hospital. A fundamentalist Islamist militant group named '[[Ansarullah Bangla Team|Ansar al Islam Bangladesh-2]]' claimed responsibility for the attack. On a social media website, the group declared: "Our Mujahideens [fighters] executed a 'Murtad' [apostate] today in Rajshahi who had prohibited female students in his department to wear '[[burqa|Burka]]' [veil]."<ref name=bdnews24_16nov2014/> The website also quoted a 2010 article from a newspaper affiliated with Jamaat-e-Islami stating that "Professor Shafiul Islam, while being the chair of the sociology department, recruited teachers on condition of being clean-shaved and not wearing kurta-pajamas. He barred female students from wearing burka in classes. This led to many students abandoning burka against their will."<ref name=bdnews24_16nov2014/>
According to one of Shafiul Islam's colleagues, the victim was not anti-Islam but had prohibited female students from wearing full-face veils in his classes as he believed they could be used to cheat in exams.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bangladesh professor who pushed for ban on full-face veils hacked to death: police |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/south-asia/bangladesh-professor-who-pushed-for-ban-on-full-face-veils-hacked-to-death-police |work=The Straits Times |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=16 November 2014}}</ref>
=== Avijit Roy === [[File:Bonya Ahmed - We Stand on the Right Side of History.webm|thumb|[[Bonya Ahmed]] speaking about the attack (18:54), and putting it in a broader context.]] On 26 February 2015 bio-engineer Dr. [[Avijit Roy]], a well-known Bangladeshi blogger, and his wife [[Bonya Ahmed]] were attacked in Dhaka by machete-wielding assailants.<ref name=guardian_28feb2015/><ref name=USAtheist>{{cite news|title=Atheist US blogger hacked to death in Bangladesh|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/bangladesh/11438812/Atheist-US-blogger-hacked-to-death-in-Bangladesh.html|accessdate=27 February 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=27 February 2015}}</ref> Roy and his wife had been returning home from the [[Ekushey Book Fair]] by bicycle [[rickshaw]]<ref name=guardian_28feb2015/> when around 8:30 p.m. they were attacked near the [[Teacher-Student Centre, University of Dhaka|Teacher Student Center intersection of Dhaka University]] by unidentified assailants. According to witnesses, two assailants stopped and dragged them from the rickshaw to the pavement before striking them with machetes.<ref name=guardian_28feb2015/> Roy was struck and stabbed in the head with sharp weapons. His wife was slashed on her shoulders and the fingers of her left hand severed when she attempted to go to her husband's aid.<ref name="na26022015">{{cite news|url=http://newagebd.net/98434/blogger-avijit-hacked-to-death-on-du-campus/#sthash.Vp1lYqIQ.dpbs|title=Blogger Avijit hacked to death on DU campus|date=26 February 2015|work=New Age|accessdate=26 February 2015|location=Dhaka}}</ref> Both were rushed to [[Dhaka Medical College Hospital]], where Roy died at 10:30 p.m. His wife survived the attack.<ref>{{cite news |title=Writer Avijit Roy hacked to death |url=http://archive.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2015/feb/26/writer-avijit-roy-killed-miscreants-attack |work=Dhaka Tribune |date=26 February 2015}}</ref>
Roy was a naturalized U.S. citizen and founder of the influential Bangladeshi blog ''[[Mukto-Mona]]'' ("Freethinkers"). A champion of liberal [[secularism]] and [[humanism]], Roy was an outspoken atheist and opponent of religious extremism. He was the author of ten books, the best known of which was a critique of religious extremism, ''Virus of Faith''.<ref name=guardian_28feb2015/> A group calling itself Ansar Bangla{{nbsp}}7 claimed responsibility for the attack, describing Roy's writings as a "crime against Islam".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Alam |first1=Julhas |date=27 February 2015 |title=American blogger, secular activist hacked to death with meat cleavers in Bangladesh |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/world/american-blogger-secular-activist-hacked-to-death-with-meat-cleavers-in-bangladesh |work=National Post |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> They also stated that he was targeted as a U.S. citizen in retaliation for U.S. bombing of ISIS militants in Syria.<ref name=dailymail_1mar2015>{{cite news |last1=Corcoran |first1=Kieran |last2=Matthew |first2=Sam |date=27 February 2015 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2971508/American-blogger-spoke-against-religious-extremism-hacked-death-Muslim-militant-group-Bangladeshi-street-walked-wife.html |title=Moment Avijit Roy's wife was left next to her husband's body after he was hacked to death |work=Daily Mail}}</ref>
Roy's killing sparked protests in Dhaka and brought forth expressions of concern internationally.<ref name=guardian_28feb2015/> UNESCO Director-General [[Irina Bokova]] called for the perpetrators to be brought to justice, and for the government to defend freedom of expression and public debate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/unesco/about-us/who-we-are/director-general/singleview-dg/news/director_general_urges_action_to_bring_the_killers_of_blogger_washiqur_rahman_babu_to_trial/|title=Director-General urges Action to bring the killers of blogger Washiqur Rahman Babu to trial|date=9 April 2015|publisher=UNESCO Press}}</ref> Author [[Tahmima Anam]] wrote in ''[[The New York Times]]'': "Blogging has become a dangerous profession in Bangladesh", stating that writers have rallied at Dhaka University to criticise the authorities for "not doing enough to safeguard freedom of expression".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/04/opinion/tahmima-anam-save-bangladeshs-bloggers.html|title=Save Bangladesh's Bloggers|author=Tahmina Anam|date=3 April 2015|work=New York Times Opinion}}</ref> Anam wrote {{quote|[Avijit Roy] and Mr. Rahman were the victims of murderous thugs, but they were also the victims of a poisonous political climate, in which secularists and Islamists, observant Muslims and atheists, Jamaat-e-Islami and the Awami League are pitted against one another. They battle for votes, for power, for the ideological upper hand. There seems to be no common ground.}}
[[Mahfuz Anam]], editor of [[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|''The Daily Star'']], wrote that the death "is a spine-chilling warning to us all that we all can be targets. All that needs to happen for any of us to be killed is that some fanatic somewhere in the country, decides that someone or anyone, needs to be killed." Anam stated: {{quote|We believe that diversity, tolerance and freedom of conscience – fundamental to our existence – are being challenged here... What is being destroyed is an integral part of the values of our freedom struggle and the democratic struggle that we have waged so far.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dangerous desensitisation|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/dangerous-desensitisation-75309|work=The Daily Star|date=3 April 2015}}</ref>}}
=== Washiqur Rahman === On 30 March 2015 another blogger, Washiqur Rahman, was killed in the Tejgaon neighborhood of Dhaka in an attack similar to that perpetrated on Avijit Roy. The police arrested two suspects near the scene and recovered [[meat cleaver]]s from them. The suspects said they killed Raman because of his anti-Islamic articles. Raman was reportedly known for criticizing "irrational religious beliefs".<ref name=Oyasiqur>{{cite news |title=Knife attack kills Bangladesh blogger Washiqur Rahman |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32112433 |work=BBC News |date=30 March 2015 |accessdate=31 March 2015}}</ref> The suspects informed the police that they are also members of the Ansarullah Bangla Team and had trained for fifteen days before killing the blogger.<ref>{{cite news |date=2 April 2015 |title=Ansarullah behind Wasiq murder: DMP |url=http://www.observerbd.com/2015/04/02/81400.php |location=Dhaka |newspaper=The Daily Observer |access-date=11 May 2015}}</ref>
Imran Sarker told reporters that, unlike Roy, Raman was not a high-profile blogger, but "was targeted because open-minded and progressive bloggers are being targeted in general. They are killing those who are easy to access, when they get the opportunity... The main attempt is to create fear among bloggers."<ref name=dw_30mar2015/> According to Sarker, Raman's murder was part of a "struggle between those who are promoting political Islam to turn Bangladesh into a fundamentalist, religious state and the secular political forces ... That is why [the bloggers] have become the main target, and the political parties who are supposed to prevent such attacks and provide security to them seem unable to do so. The main problem is that even mainstream political parties prefer to compromise with these radical groups to remain in power".<ref name=dw_30mar2015/>
The [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] issued a press release stating that Raman's death occurred in a climate of "official harassment of journalists in Bangladesh".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cpj.org/2015/04/cpj-concerned-by-arrest-of-bangladeshi-journalist-.php |title=CPJ concerned by arrest of Bangladeshi journalist and his treatment in custody |date=1 April 2015 |website=Committee to Protect Journalists}}</ref>
=== Ananta Bijoy Das === Ananta Bijoy Das, an atheist blogger<ref name=cnn_13may2015/> who was on an extremist hit-list for his writing, was hacked to death by four masked men in [[Sylhet]] on 12{{nbsp}}May 2015.<ref name=cnn_13may2015/> Ananta wrote blogs for ''Mukto-Mona''. He had authored three books on science, evolution, and revolution in the Soviet Union, and headed the Sylhet-based science and rationalist council.<ref>{{cite news |date=12 May 2015 |title=Slain blogger Ananta Bijoy Das' last words in 'devil's world' |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/05/12/slain-blogger-ananta-bijoy-das-last-words-in-devils-world |newspaper=bdnews24.com |access-date=14 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{cite news |author=Saad Hammadi |title=Third atheist blogger killed in Bangladesh knife attack |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/12/third-atheist-blogger-killed-in-bangladesh-after-knife-attack |newspaper=[[the Guardian]] |agency=AgenceFrance-Presse |access-date=14 May 2015}}</ref> He was also an editor of a quarterly magazine called ''Jukti'' (Logic).<ref name=":2" />
Ananta Das was invited by the Swedish PEN to discuss the persecution of writers in Bangladesh, but the Swedish government refused him a visa on the grounds that he might not return to Bangladesh after his visit.<ref name=guardianeditorial/>
Lawyer Sara Hossain said of Roy and Das, "They've always believed and written very vocally in support of free expression and they've very explicitly written about not following any religion themselves."<ref>{{cite news |date=12 May 2015 |title=Bangladesh blogger Ananta Bijoy Das hacked to death |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32701001 |work=BBC News}}</ref> Asia director of [[Human Rights Watch]] Brad Adams said of Ananta's killing, "This pattern of vicious attacks on secular and atheist writers not only silences the victims but also sends a chilling message to all in Bangladesh who espouse independent views on religious issues."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/05/12/bangladesh-killing-blogger-blow-free-speech |title=Bangladesh: Killing of Blogger Blow to Free Speech |website=Human Rights Watch |access-date=14 May 2015}}</ref>
An editorial in ''[[The Guardian]]'' stated: "Like [[Raif Badawi]], imprisoned and flogged in [[Saudi Arabia]], the brave men who have been murdered are guilty of nothing more than honesty and integrity. Those are virtues that fundamentalists and fanatics cannot stand."<ref name=guardianeditorial>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/may/12/guardian-view-on-murder-of-ananta-bijoy-das|title=The Guardian view on the murder of Ananta Bijoy Das: an assault on a universal value|work=The Guardian (editorial)|date=12 May 2015}}</ref> The editorial concluded, "Violent jihadis have circulated a list with more than 80 names of free thinkers whom they wish to kill. The public murder of awkward intellectuals is one definition of barbarism. Governments of the west, and that of Bangladesh, must do much more to defend freedom and to protect lives."<ref name="guardianeditorial" />
=== Niloy Chakroborty === Niloy Chatterjee,<ref name="Star">{{cite news |date=8 August 2015 |title=Blogger killed once again |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/blogger-killed-once-again-123493 |newspaper=The Daily Star |access-date=8 August 2015}}</ref> also known as Niloy Chakroborty<ref name="reuters">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUKKCN0QC15020150807?irpc=932|title=Blogger hacked to death in Bangladesh, fourth this year|work=Reuters|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> and by his pen name Niloy Neel, was killed on 7{{nbsp}}August 2015. It is reported that a gang of about six men armed with machetes attacked him at his home in the Goran neighborhood of Dhaka and hacked him to death.<ref name="cnn_7aug2015">{{cite web |last1=Pokharel |first1=Sugam |last2=Smith-Spark |first2=Laura |date=7 August 2015 |title=Bangladeshi blogger Niloy Neel hacked to death in latest attack |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/07/asia/bangladesh-blogger-niloy-neel-killed/index.html |work=CNN |access-date=7 August 2015}}</ref> Police said that the men had tricked his wife<ref name="Star" /> into allowing them into their home before killing him. His best friend Sahedul Sahed said ,Neel had previously reported to the police that he feared for his life, but no action had been taken.<ref name="BBC Neel">{{cite news |title=Bangladesh blogger Niloy Neel hacked to death in Dhaka |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-33819032 |work=BBC News |date=7 August 2015 |accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref> He was an organiser of the Science and Rationalist Association Bangladesh, and had obtained a master's degree in Philosophy from [[Dhaka University]] in 2013.<ref name="India Today Neel">{{cite magazine |title=Niloy Neel, fourth secular blogger killed in Bangladesh this year |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/fourth-secular-blogger-murdered-in-bangladesh/1/456996.html |magazine=[[India Today]] |date=7 August 2015 |accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref> Niloy had written in ''Mukto-Mona'', a blogging platform for secularists and freethinkers,<ref name="cnn_7aug2015" /> was associated with the Shahbag Movement;<ref>{{cite news |date=7 August 2015 |title=Un grupo yihadista reivindica el asesinato de un bloguero en Bangladesh |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/yihadista-reivindica-asesinato-bloguero-Bangladesh_0_417508779.html |newspaper=El Diario |language=es |agency=EFE |access-date=7 August 2015}}</ref> he and his friend Sahedul Sahed had attended the public protest demanding justice for the murdered bloggers, Ananta Bijoy Das and Avijit Roy.<ref>{{cite news |date=7 August 2015 |title=Bangladesh: Secular blogger Niloy Neel hacked to death in Islamist militant attack |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/bangladesh-secular-blogger-niloy-neel-hacked-death-islamist-militant-attack-1514526 |newspaper=International Business Times |access-date=7 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Secular blogger Niloy Neel hacked to death in Bangladesh |url=http://www.dw.com/en/secular-blogger-niloy-neel-hacked-to-death-in-bangladesh/a-18633856 |work=[[Deutsche Welle]] |access-date=7 August 2015}}</ref> Ansarullah Al Islam Bangladesh, an [[Al Qaeda]] group,<ref name="cnn_7aug2015" /> claimed responsibility for Niloy's killing.<ref>{{cite news |author=Monideepa Banerjie |date=7 August 2015 |title=4th Secular Blogger Killed In Bangladesh In 6 Months |url=http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/niloy-neel-bangladeshi-secular-blogger-hacked-to-death-in-his-home-1205028 |work=[[NDTV]] |access-date=7 August 2015}}</ref>
The UN urged a quick and fair investigation of the murder saying, "It is vital to ensure the identification of those responsible for this and the previous horrendous crimes, as well as those who may have masterminded the attacks."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO1508/S00032/bangladesh-un-experts-condemn-killing-of-blogger-niloy-neel.htm|title=Bangladesh: UN experts condemn killing of blogger Niloy Neel|work=scoop.co.nz|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> Amnesty International condemned the killing and said that it was the "urgent duty (of the government) to make clear that no more attacks like this will be tolerated".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2015/aug/08/niloy-murder-amnesty-calls-trial-killers|title=Niloy murder: Amnesty calls for trial of killers |work=Dhaka Tribune |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> Other entities condemning the killing include the [[German Government]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/crime/2015/aug/10/german-embassy-condemns-niloy-murder|title=Germany condemns Niloy murder |work=Dhaka Tribune |accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref> [[Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami]], Bangladeshi prime minister [[Sheikh Hasina]],<ref>{{cite news |date=8 August 2015 |title=Bangladesh PM, Jamaat condemn blogger's murder |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/bangladesh-pm-jamaat-condemn-blogger-s-murder-115080800696_1.html |newspaper=Business Standard |agency=IANS |access-date=10 August 2015}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]],<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/08/11/bangladesh-stop-promoting-self-censorship|title = Bangladesh: Stop Promoting Self-Censorship|date = 11 August 2015|accessdate = 15 August 2015|website = [[Human Rights Watch]]|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> the [[Communist Party of Bangladesh]], [[Gonojagoron Moncho]], and other political parties of Bangladesh, both rightist and leftist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2015/aug/08/moncho-rights-bodies-condemn-niloy-murder|title=Moncho, rights bodies condemn Niloy murder |work=Dhaka Tribune |accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref>
Writer [[Taslima Nasrin]] criticized the prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, and her government saying, "Sheikh Hasina's government is morally culpable. I am squarely blaming the state for these massacres in installment. Its indifference and so-called inability to rein in the murderous Ansarullah brigade is solely predicated on the fear of being labelled atheists."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.dailyo.in/politics/niloy-neel-murder-bangladesh-writer-hacked-to-death/story/1/5545.html|title = Why I blame Sheikh Hasina for Niloy Neel's death|date = 8 August 2015|accessdate = 15 August 2015|website = [[The Daily O]]|publisher = |last = Nasreen|first = Taslima}}</ref>
=== Faisal Arefin Dipan === [[Faisal Arefin Dipan]], aged 43, the publisher of [[Jagriti Prakashani]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jagritibooks.com/যোগাযোগ |title=যোগাযোগ |trans-title=Contacts |publisher=Jagriti Prakashani |accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> which published Avijit Roy's ''Biswasher Virus'' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]] for ''The Virus of Faith''),<ref>{{cite web |author=Avijit Roy |authorlink=Avijit Roy |url=https://www.goodreads.com/author_blog_posts/7731870-the-virus-of-faith |title=The Virus of Faith |work=অভিজিৎ রায়'s Blog |date=21 January 2015 |accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> was hacked to death in Dhaka on 31{{nbsp}}October 2015. Reports stated that he had been killed in his third-floor office at the Jagriti Prokashoni publishing house. The attack followed another stabbing, earlier the same day, in which publisher [[Ahmedur Rashid Chowdhury]] and two writers, Ranadeep Basu and Tareque Rahim, were stabbed in their office at another publishing house. The three men were taken to hospital, and at least one was reported to be in critical condition.<ref>{{cite web |date=31 October 2015 |title=Bangladeshi secular publisher hacked to death|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-34688245 |website = BBC News|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref>
===Ahmedur Rashid Chowdhury (Tutul)===
[[Ahmedur Rashid Chowdhury]] Tutul, aged 43, editor and publisher of ''Shuddhashar'' In February 2015, he received a death threat, for publishing books of atheist writers and his secular view. On October 31, 2015, he was attacked by assailants with machetes. He was hospitalized in a critical condition. Ansar Al Islam (AQIS Bangladesh) claimed the responsibility.<ref>{{cite news |last=Flood |first=Alison |date=13 October 2016 |title=Margaret Atwood selects Tutul for Pen writer of courage award |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/oct/13/margaret-atwood-selects-tutul-for-pen-writer-of-courage-award |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=27 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Tutul wins PEN Int'l Writer of Courage award |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/backpage/tutul-wins-pen-intl-writer-courage-award-1298908 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=15 October 2016 |access-date=27 February 2017}}</ref>
===Shahjahan Bachchu=== Shahjahan Bachchu an acting editor of weekly Amader Bikrampur and former general secretary of Munshiganj chapter of Communist Party of Bangladesh shot dead on 11 June 2018.<ref name="Daily star12">{{cite news |title=Bachchcu murder suspect killed in ‘gunfight’ |url=https://www.thedailystar.net/country/writer-publisher-shahjahan-bachchcu-murder-suspect-killed-in-gunfight-1596685 |accessdate=24 August 2018 |work=The Daily Star |date=28 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref> His daughter said to the [[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|Daily Star]] that when bloggers were being killed one after another in Bangladesh, her father received threats on his mobile phones on a number of occasions.He had his own publishing house “Bishaka Prokashoni”.<ref>{{cite news |title=Assailants shoot publisher dead in Munshiganj |url=https://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/ex-cpb-leader-shot-dead-munshiganj-1589782 |accessdate=24 August 2018 |work=The Daily Star |date=12 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Main suspect of that murder named Abdur Rahman arrested on June 24 and according to the police press he got killed by gunfight on 28 June 2018.<ref name="Daily star12" />
== Broader attacks == After an initial wave of attacks focused solely on secularists, most of them atheists, the targets broadened to include other activists, members of religious minority groups, and representatives of Bengali or western culture. Some of these attacks are reported to have been regretted by the murderers associated with one of the perpetrating groups, [[Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen Bangladesh]]. They admitted that they had bungled their research, choosing victims who had not offended Islam but were simply popular figures in the community.<ref name="NYT8June2016" />
===Kunio Hoshi=== {{nihongo|Kunio Hoshi|星邦男|''Hoshi Kunio''}} was a 66-year-old Japanese man from [[Iwate Prefecture]] who was shot in Rangpur, Bangladesh, in October 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/articles/ASHB35W3NHB3UHBI011.html |title=日本人男性、撃たれ死亡 バングラデシュで移動中] |trans-title=Japanese man shot dead while travelling in Bangladesh |work=[[Asahi Shimbun]] |date= 3 October 2015 |access-date=2 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/10/07/national/crime-legal/bangladesh-holding-opposition-activist-businessman-iwate-farmers-slaying/ |title=Bangladesh holding opposition activist, businessman in Iwate farmer's slaying |work=[[Japan Times]] |date= 7 October 2015 |access-date= 2 July 2016}}</ref> Hoshi was also known by the [[alias name|aliases]] Hita Kuchi and Golam Kibria.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The untold tale of Hoshi Kunio |url = http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2015/oct/06/untold-tale-hoshi-kunio|website = www.dhakatribune.com|accessdate = 31 October 2015}}</ref> Hoshi first went to Bangladesh in 2011 and had visited every year since.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Pastor escapes being killed in Bangladesh days after Japanese man is murdered|url = http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/10/06/national/crime-legal/bangladesh-police-quiz-four-iwate-mans-murder-tokyo-decries-slaying/|newspaper = [[The Japan Times Online]]|date = 6 October 2015|access-date = 31 October 2015|issn = 0447-5763}}</ref> He last arrived in June 2015, approximately four months before his death. Hoshi was shot three times in a remote rural region of Rangpur, where he had invested in a grass cultivation project and had leased land for [[Bangladeshi taka|Tk82,000]]. According to police sources, Hoshi was not a wealthy man and had come to Bangladesh to improve his condition, adding that the relatively low cost of living in Bangladesh and its rich soil drove him to try his luck in Bangladesh.<ref>{{Cite news|title = IS claims killing of Japanese in Bangladesh|url = http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/10/04/national/islamic-state-claims-responsibility-killing-japanese-man-bangladesh/|newspaper = The Japan Times Online|date = 4 October 2015|access-date = 31 October 2015|issn = 0447-5763|first = Jesse|last = Johnson}}</ref> The Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant [[ISIL]] claimed responsibility for killing Hoshi on Twitter, according to the SITE Intelligence Group, a US monitoring organization.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Masked gunmen kill Japanese national in Bangladesh|url = http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/10/masked-gunmen-kill-japanese-national-bangladesh-151003192857965.html|website = www.aljazeera.com|accessdate = 31 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Unidentified assailants kill a Japanese national in Rangpur|url = http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/10/03/unidentified-assailants-kill-a-japanese-national-in-rangpur|website = bdnews24.com|accessdate = 31 October 2015}}</ref> His murderers told investigators that they had bungled their research and did not realize that Kunio had converted to Islam.<ref name="NYT8June2016" /> The Japanese Embassy of Bangladesh argued that Hoshi should be buried in Bangladesh, with an Islamic-style ceremony. He was ultimately buried in Bangladesh.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/10/13/national/crime-legal/burial-held-japanese-man-killed-bangladesh/ |title=Burial held for Japanese man killed in Bangladesh |work=[[Japan Times]] |date= 13 October 2015 |access-date=2 July 2016}}</ref>
=== Jogeshwar Roy === On 21 February 2016 the so-called Islamic State group has said it was behind the beheading of Jogeshwar Roy, a senior [[Hindu]] priest, and the wounding of two worshippers in the Panchagarh district of northern Bangladesh.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/jogeshwar-roy-hindu-priest-hacked-death-bangladesh-temple-attack-a6887121.html|title=Hindu priest hacked to death in Bangladesh|date=2016-02-21|website=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-06-07}}</ref>
=== Rezaul Karim Siddique === On 23 April 2016 [[A. F. M. Rezaul Karim Siddique]], a professor of English at the [[University of Rajshahi]], was hacked to death by several unidentified assailants while waiting for a bus to the university campus in Rajshahi city.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bangladesh Police Suspect Islamist Militants in Professor’s Killing |author=Julfikar Ali Manik and Ellen Barry |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/24/world/asia/bangladesh-professor-killed.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=23 April 2016 |accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref> ISIL later claimed responsibility for his death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Islamic State claims responsibility for murder of Bangladeshi professor|url=http://dailytimes.com.pk/world/25-Apr-16/islamic-state-claims-responsibility-for-murder-of-bangladeshi-professor|website=Daily Times|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref>
=== Xulhaz Mannan and Mahbub Rabbi Tonoy === Two days after Siddique's murder (25 April 2016), gay-rights activists [[Xulhaz Mannan]] and Mahbub Rabbi Tonoy were hacked to death by assailants who broke into Mannan's apartment in the Kalabagan neighborhood of Dhaka. Mannan was the editor of Bangladesh's first [[LGBT]]-themed magazine ''[[Roopbaan]]'' and an employee of [[USAID]], Bangladesh. Tonoy was a prominent theater activist and co-organizer of the [https://roopbaan.org/2017/09/23/roopbaan-rainbow-rally-2014-2015/ Rainbow Rally 2015]. ISIL claimed responsibility for the attack.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36128729|title=Bangladesh LGBT editor hacked to death|website=[[BBC News]]|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref>
=== Nikhil Joarder === On 30 April 2016 Nikhil Joarder, a Hindu tailor, was hacked to death by two assailants in Tangail in central Bangladesh, by several men on a motorcycle. Responsibililty for the crime was quickly claimed by the organization Islamic State through the news agency of the terrorist group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rfi.fr/asie-pacifique/20160430-bangladesh-tailleur-hindou-assassinat-islamistes-ei?ref=tw_i&dlvrit=1448817|title=Bangladesh: le groupe EI revendique le meurtre d'un tailleur hindou|date=30 April 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Mohammad Shahidullah === On 7 May 2016 suspected Islamic militants hacked to death a 65-year-old minority [[Sufi Muslim]] man, Mohammad Shahidullah, at a mango grove in [[Mymensingh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/2016/05/07/Bangladesh-Sufi-Muslim-killed-in-suspected-Islamist-attack-.html|title=Bangladesh Sufi Muslim killed in suspected Islamist attack|website=english.alarabiya.net}}</ref>
=== Maung Shue U Chak === Maung Shue U Chak, a 75-year-old Buddhist monk, was hacked to death in the [[Bandarban]] district of southeastern Bangladesh on 14{{nbsp}}May 2016. The Islamic State is suspected to be behind the killing.,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36292457|title=Buddhist monk killed in Bangladesh|date=14 May 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
=== Mir Sanaur Rahman and Saifuzzaman === Machete-wielding assailants hacked a village doctor to death and wounded a university teacher in the Kushtia district of Bangladesh on 20{{nbsp}}May 2016. The homeopathic doctor, Mir Sanaur Rahman, 55, was killed on the spot, and his companion, identified as Saifuzzaman, 45, suffered serious wounds. Police found a bloody machete at the scene.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bangladesh-attacks/bangladesh-village-doctor-hacked-to-death-in-suspected-islamist-attack-idUSKCN0YB0OA|title=Bangladesh village doctor hacked to death in attack claimed by Islamic|date=21 May 2016|publisher=|via=Reuters}}</ref> Mir Sanaur Rahman provided free treatment to villagers, and his murderers, who belonged to Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen Bangladesh, are said to have chosen him as a target because they bungled their research when seeking possible victims.<ref name="NYT8June2016">{{cite news |author1=Geeta Anand |author2=Julfikar Ali Manik |date=June 8, 2016 |title=Bangladesh Says It Now Knows Who's Killing the Bloggers |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/09/world/asia/bangladesh-killings-bloggers.html?_r=0 |newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>
=== Debesh Chandra Pramanik === On 25 May 2016 Debesh Chandra Pramanik, a 68-year-old Hindu businessman, was attacked and killed in his shoe shop at [[Gaibandha]] in Dhaka district. ISIL claimed responsibility for the attack, their second in [[Bangladesh]] in less than a week.<ref>{{cite news |title=Islamic State claims killing of Bangladeshi Hindu trader: SITE monitor group |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world/islamic-state-claims-killing-of-bangladeshi-hindu-trader-site-monitor-group/story-70YRfBE5SEmqxMrKV4WJDN.html |newspaper=Hindustan Times |agency=Reuters |date=26 May 2016}}</ref>
=== Ananda Gopal Ganguly === On 7 June 2016, Ananda Gopal Ganguly, a 70-year-old Hindu priest, had his throat slit by suspected Islamists in the Jhenaidaha district of the Khulna division, soon after three suspected Islamists were killed by police. He was said to have been hacked and shot at, with a cut to the throat being the death blow. Three men attacked him while he was riding on his motorcycle.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36467270|title=Hindu priest murdered in Bangladesh|date=7 June 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
=== Nityaranjan Pande === On 10 June 2016 Nityaranjan Pande, a 60-year-old worker at a Hindu monastery in Pabna, was hacked to death by several people near the monastery. Islamist militants have been suspected in his death.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36496443|title=Monastery worker killed in Bangladesh|date=10 June 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
===Ripon Chakraborty=== On 15 June 2016 Ripon Chakraborty, a Hindu college teacher in the Madaripur district was attacked with machete knives at his home by three people. He survived the attack, but was seriously injured.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bangladesh killings: Hindu teacher attacked at home|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36542018|accessdate=17 June 2016|work=BBC News|agency=[[BBC]]|date=15 June 2016}}</ref> One of the three attackers named Ghulam Faijullaha Fahim was caught while escaping and handed over to police by local people.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bangladesh questions attacker of Hindu teacher; hunts two more|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/bangladesh-violence-idINKCN0Z12BF|accessdate=17 June 2016|work=Reuters India|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=15 June 2016|language=en-IN}}</ref>
=== Shyamananda Das === On 1 July 2016 Shyamananda Das, a Hindu temple worker, was hacked to death by three suspected Islamic militants on motorcycles in the Satkhira district.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36680938|title=Bangladesh Hindu priest hacked to death|date=1 July 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref> Another two Hindu men, Surendra Sarkar and Tarak Saha, were reportedly injured by suspected Islamic militants in the attack although this has not been confirmed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hindujagruti.org/news/85094.html|title=Hindu Ayurvedic practitioner hacked to death during Ramadan in Bangladesh - Hindu Janajagruti Samiti|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Mong Shwe Lung Marma ===
On 2 July 2016 Mong Shwe Lung Marma, a Buddhist farmer and the vice president of ward seven of the [[Bangladesh Awami League|Awami league]], was hacked to death and assassinated in [[Bandarban]]. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the assassination. The victim was killed near the site of a previous killing of another Buddhist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/buddhist-al-leader-killed-bandarban-1249081|title=Buddhist AL leader killed in Bandarban|date=2 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
===Gulshan attack=== {{main article|2016 Gulshan attack}} On 1 July 2016 at around 11:30 pm local time, six militants entered and opened fire on the Holey Artisan Bakery in [[Gulshan Thana|Gulshan]], a diplomatic neighborhood of Dhaka. They also threw bombs and took several dozen hostages. A total of 28 people were killed, including 17 foreigners, two police officers, and five gunmen. One of the gunmen was captured and 13 hostages were freed by the [[Bangladesh Armed Forces]], police, [[Rapid Action Battalion|RAB]], [[Border Guards Bangladesh|BGB]], and joint forces. According to Bangladesh's Inspector General of Police, all six of the attackers were Bangladeshi citizens.
==Disputed attacks== === Nazimuddin Samad === Nazimuddin Samad (1988 – 6 April 2016) was a law student at [[Jagannath University]] and liberal blogger who was reportedly killed by suspected radical [[Islamists]] in Dhaka for his promotion of secularism in Bangladesh.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jamil Kahn |first1=Mohammad |title=JnU student killed in suspected militant attack |url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2016/apr/07/jnu-student-killed-suspected-militant-attack |newspaper=Dhaka Tribune |accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Liberal Bangladeshi blogger killed by machete-wielding attackers |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bangladesh-blogger-idUSKCN0X40FZ |work=Reuters |date=7 April 2016 |type=Editorial}}</ref> Unidentified assailants attacked Samad with a machete and shot him to death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iheu.org/atheist-student-nazimuddin-samad-killed-in-bangladesh/|title=Atheist student Nazimuddin Samad killed in Bangladesh|website=International Humanist and Ethical Union|accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{cite news |title=Nazim killed to divert attention from Tonu murder: Imran |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/nazim-killed-divert-attention-tonu-murder-imran-1205740 |work=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |date=7 April 2016 |access-date=26 February 2017}}</ref> However, [[Imran H Sarker]], convener of the [[Gonojagaran Mancha]] said that the murder had been committed by [[false flag|government collusion]] in order divert attention from the [[Murder of Sohagi Jahan Tonu|rape and killing of Sohagi Jahan Tonu]], a student of [[Comilla University]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Killing of Nazim to divert attention from Tonu murder: Imran |url=http://www.daily-sun.com/post/126737/Killing-of-Nazim-to-divert-attention-from-Tonu-murder:-Imran |newspaper=Daily Sun |date=7 April 2016 |accessdate=26 February 2017}}</ref><ref name=":5" />
=== Mahmuda Khanam Mitu === On 5 June 2016 Mahmuda Khanam Mitu, the wife of a [[Bangladesh Police|Bangladesh police]] superintendent Babul Aktar, was stabbed, shot in the head, and killed by three suspected outside of her apartment at a busy road junction in Chittagong. Her six-year-old son was present with her while she was killed. Although she was not secular or atheist, but religious, initially the killing was suspected to have been done by Islamic extremists, as her husband had headed several investigations and operation raids related to the strings of killings committed by Islamic extremists in Chittagong and was awarded.<ref>{{cite news |title=Top Bangladesh policeman's wife killed |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36454433 |work=BBC News |date=5 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Bangladeshi Christian hacked to death |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/wife-of-bangladesh-policeman-who-battled-militants-killed/article8693440.ece |newspaper=The Hindu |date=2016-06-05 |access-date=2016-06-07 |issn=0971-751X}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Cop courageous |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/cop-courageous-1234960 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=2016-06-05 |access-date=2016-06-07}}</ref> The killings were however condemned by Ansar al-Islam, the suspected Bangladesh chapter of [[al-Qaeda in the Indian Subcontinent]].<ref name=":0">{{cite news |title=SP Babul Akter freed after 'interrogation' |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/sp-babul-akhter-police-custody-1245445 |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |date=15 June 2016 |access-date=26 February 2017}}</ref> However, in 2017 Mitu's father, Md Mosharraf Hossain said that [[circumstantial evidence]] led him to believe that Babul himself had orchestrated his wife's murder.<ref name=":4">{{cite news |last1=Rabbi |first1=Arifur Rahman |date=19 February 2017|title=Mitu’s father suspects Babul |url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/crime/2017/02/19/mitus-father-suspects-babul/ |newspaper=[[Dhaka Tribune]] |accessdate=26 February 2017}}</ref> This allegations arose Babul was alleged to have an extramarital affair Bonani Binte Bonni, wife of deceased [[Special Branch]] Sub-Inspector Akram Hossain Liton.<ref name=":4" /> Babul hade been previously interrogated by police on several occasions.<ref name=":0" /> As of February 2017, police were investigating [[organized crime|listed criminal]] Kamrul Islam Musa, a former [[informant]] who had served under Babul Aktar and his accomplice Nabi.<ref name=":4"/>
== Earlier attacks ==
=== Taslima Nasrin === In the 1990s author Taslima Nasrin achieved notoriety in Bangladesh for "her bold use of sexual imagery in her poetry, her self-declared atheism, and her iconoclastic lifestyle".<ref name="literature"/> In her newspaper columns and books, she criticized rising religious fundamentalism and government inaction. In early 1992 mobs began attacking book stores stocking her work. The same year she was assaulted at a book fair and her passport was confiscated. In July 1993 her novel ''[[Lajja]]'' was banned by the government for allegedly creating "misunderstanding among communities".<ref>{{cite news |title = Bangladesh Teacher arrested for having a copy of a book by Taslima Nasrin, – Asia News|url = http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Teacher-arrested-for-having-a-copy-of-a-book-by-Taslima-Nasrin,-23622.html|website = asianews.it|accessdate = 16 May 2015}}</ref> On 23{{nbsp}}September 1993 a [[fatwa]] was issued for her death. After international pressure, her passport was returned in April 1994, after which she traveled to France and returned via India. On 4{{nbsp}}July 1994, an arrest warrant was issued for her under an old statute dating to the [[British Raj|British colonial period]] outlawing writings "intended to outrage ... religious believers", and she went underground.<ref name="literature"/> After being granted bail on 3{{nbsp}}August, Nasrin fled to Sweden, remaining in exile for some years. In 1998 she visited her critically ill mother in Bangladesh but was forced to go into hiding once again after threats and demonstrations. In 2005 she moved to India and applied for citizenship.<ref name="literature">{{cite book|author=Margaret Bald|title=Literature Suppressed on Religious Grounds|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SMiqYHR6xkMC&pg=PA177|accessdate=27 January 2014|date=1 January 2006|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-7148-7|page=177}}</ref>
=== Shamsur Rahman === On 18 January 1999 [[Shamsur Rahman (poet)|Shamsur Rahman]], a leading Bangladeshi poet, was targeted, and a failed attempt was made by [[Harakat-Ul-Jihad-Ul-Islami]] to kill him at his residence for his writings.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Griswold|first1=Eliza|title=The Next Islamist Revolution?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/01/23/magazine/the-next-islamist-revolution.html?_r=0|accessdate=19 August 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 January 2005}}</ref>
=== Humayun Azad === {{Main article|Humayun Azad}} In 2003 Bangladeshi secular author and critic [[Humayun Azad]] wrote a book named ''[[Pak Sar Jamin Sad Bad|Pak Sar Jamin Saad Baad]]'' criticising the political party, [[Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami]]. Azad received numerous death threats from fundamentalist groups after its publication.<ref name="Daily Star">{{cite news |date=12 August 2009 |title=Proper probe into death of Humayun Azad demanded |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=101061 |newspaper=The Daily Star}}</ref> On 27{{nbsp}}February 2004, he became the victim of an assassination attempt by assailants armed with machetes near the campus of the [[University of Dhaka]] during the annual [[Ekushey Book Fair]]. A week prior to that assault, [[Delwar Hossain Sayeedi]], a Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami leader and then member of the parliament, demanded in the parliament that Azad's political satire ''Pak Sar Jamin Saad Baad'' be banned and called for the application of the [[Blasphemy law in Bangladesh|Blasphemy Act]] to the author.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zaman |first1=Mustafa |last2=Hussain |first2=Ahmede |date=2004 |title=Humayun Azad: A Truncated Life |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/magazine/2004/09/01/cover.htm |work=Star Weekend Magazine |publisher=The Daily Star}}</ref>
On 12 August 2004 Azad was found dead in his apartment in [[Munich]], Germany, where he had arrived a week earlier to conduct research on the 19th-German romantic poet [[Heinrich Heine]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Humayun Azad found dead in Munich |author= |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/2004/08/14/d4081401011.htm |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |date=14 August 2004 |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> His family demanded an investigation, alleging that the extremists who had attempted the earlier assassination had a role in this death.<ref name="Daily Star" />
== Suspects and arrests == On 26 April 2006 a Majlish-e-Shura member of [[Jama'atul Mujahideen Bangladesh]] named Salahuddin was arrested by RAB from [[Chittagong]] as a suspected attacker on Humayun Azad. Salahuddin, accused in 33 cases, was given the death penalty for another murder case.<ref>{{cite news |date=24 February 2014 |title=An 'attacker' of Humayun Azad |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/an-attacker-of-humayun-azad-12725 |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |access-date=19 August 2015}}</ref>
On 2 March 2013 the Bangladesh Detective Bureau arrested five members of the extremist organisation Ansarullah Bangla Team for the murder of Ahmed Rajib Haider.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/crime/2015/jul/30/2-more-testify-blogger-rajeeb-murder-case|title=2 more testify in blogger Rajeeb murder case |work=Dhaka Tribune |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> The five, all students of [[North South University]], confessed to the crime in front of a magistrate.<ref name="conf">{{cite news | title = 'Shibir leader behind Rajib murder’ | publisher = [[bdnews24.com]] | url = http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2013/03/10/shibir-leader-behind-rajib-murder | date = 10 March 2013 }}</ref>
On 2 March 2015 the RAB arrested Farabi Shafiur Rahman, a radical Islamist, as a suspected murderer of Avijit Roy. It was suspected by the police that Farabi had provided Roy's location, identity, and family photographs to various people.<ref>{{cite news|title = Atheist blogger Avijit Roy 'was not just a person … he was a movement'|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/07/atheist-blogger-avijit-roy-returning-bangladesh-risky|accessdate = 7 March 2015|work = [[The Guardian]]}}</ref> Farabi had threatened Roy several times through blogs and social media sites including [[Facebook]]. He said on different posts and comments that Roy would be killed upon his arrival in Dhaka.<ref>{{cite news |date=2 March 2015 |title=Bangladesh Avijit Roy murder: Suspect arrested |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-31690514 |access-date=2 March 2015 |work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date = 2 March 2015 |title = Bangladesh authorities arrest man over atheist blogger's murder |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/02/bangladesh-authorities-arrest-man-atheist-bloggers-murder-avijit-roy |work=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=2 March 2015}}</ref>
On 14 August 2015 Bangladesh police said that they had arrested two men, suspected to be members of the Ansarullah Bangla Team, in connection with the murder of Niloy Neel.<ref name=":1">{{cite news |date=14 August 2015 |title=Two arrested over Bangladesh blogger Niloy Neel killing |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-33926342 |work=BBC News}}</ref>
On 18 August 2015 three members of Ansarullah Bangla Team, including a British citizen named Touhidur Rahman who police described as "the main planner of the attacks on Avijit Roy and Ananta Bijoy Das", had been arrested in connection with the two murders.<ref>{{cite news |date=18 August 2015 |title=Bangladesh arrests British citizen, said to be 'main planner' of murders of two bloggers |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/south-asia/bangladesh-arrests-british-citizen-said-to-be-main-planner-of-murders-of-two |newspaper=Straits Times}}</ref>
=== Death sentences in the Ahmed Rajib Haider case === Ahmed Rajib Haider's murder case was handled by a "fast-track trial court".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/bangladesh-court-awards-death-2-life-term-1-bloggers-murder-661570|title=Bangladesh court awards death to 2, life term to 1 for blogger's murder|website=International Business Times, India Edition|language=en|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref> On 30{{nbsp}}December 2015, just under three years later, two members of Ansarullah Bangla Team{{snd}}Md Faisal Bin Nayem and Redwanul Azad Rana{{snd}}were found guilty of murder and sentenced to death for Rajib Haider's murder. Faisal, the court said, was the one who attacked Haider with a meat cleaver.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-35204243|title=Death for Bangladesh blogger killers – BBC News|website=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref> Rana absconded and was sentenced in absentia. Another member of the outlawed group, Maksudul Hasan, was also guilty of murder and given a life sentence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/12/sentenced-death-murdering-bangladesh-blogger-151231085325271.html|title=Two sentenced to death for murdering Bangladesh blogger|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref> Five other members of ABT, including firebrand leader Mufti Jasim Uddin Rahmani, received jail terms of five to ten years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-2-sentenced-to-death-for-killing-secular-blogger-in-bangladesh-2161051|title=2 sentenced to death for killing secular blogger in Bangladesh|website=dna|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref> One person was given a term of three years.
