{{Infobox musical artist | embed = yes | background = solo_singer | origin = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | occupation = {{hlist|[[Poet]]|[[rapper]]|[[playwright]]}} | genre = [[Canadian hip hop]] | years_active = 2004–present | website = {{url|BabaBrinkman.com}} }}
}}
'''Dirk Murray''' "'''Baba'''" '''Brinkman''' (born October 22, 1978) is a Canadian [[rapper]] and [[playwright]] best known for recordings and performances that combine [[hip hop]] music with [[literature]], [[theatre]], and [[science]].
== Early life ==
Born in the remote community of [[Riondel, British Columbia|Riondel]], British Columbia, in a log cabin built by his parents,<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/28/science/28rap.html New York Times Article “Paying Homage to Darwin in an Unconventional Format: Rap”]</ref> Brinkman is the eldest of three children of [[Joyce Murray]], a Member of the [[Parliament of Canada]], and Dirk Brinkman, Sr., who is notable for having founded the world's only private company responsible for planting more than one billion trees.<ref>[http://walrusmagazine.com/articles/2011.09-profile-the-money-tree/ The Walrus Article “The Money Tree”]</ref> Dirk Sr gave Brinkman the honorific nickname "[[Baba (honorific)|Baba]]" at birth, because of his son's contemplative, Buddha-like expression.<ref>[http://skepchick.se/2011/05/24/intervju-med-baba-brinkman/ Skepchick Article “Interview with Baba Brinkman”]</ref> Brinkman's childhood was divided between Vancouver and the [[Kootenays|Kootenay]] region of British Columbia.<ref>[https://www.eenews.net/stories/1060044358 Energy Wire Article “Meet Baba Brinkman”]</ref>
== Education and Forestry Work ==
Brinkman spent his early summers in remote [[tree planting]] camps, and began planting trees himself at the age of 15.<ref>[http://vanmag.com/uncategorized/fresh-prince-of-east-van-2/ Vancouver Magazine Article “Fresh Prince of East Van”]</ref> He worked for his parents' business, Brinkman & Associates Reforestation, for twelve seasons in [[British Columbia]] and [[Alberta]], personally planting more than one million trees.<ref>[http://www.brinkmanreforestation.ca/millionaires-club?page=5 Brinkman & Associates Millionaire’s Circle]</ref> During this period he also earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in English Literature from [[Simon Fraser University]] and a Master of Arts degree in Comparative Literature from the [[University of Victoria]], Canada. He studied human evolution and primatology with the orangutan researcher [[Biruté Galdikas]]<ref>[https://twitter.com/DrBirute/statuses/561502941300162561 Birute Galdikas Twitter]</ref> and wrote his thesis comparing modern Hip hop freestyle battling with [[The Canterbury Tales]] by [[Geoffrey Chaucer]].<ref>[http://www.bababrinkman.com/doc/rct/prologue.pdf Rap Canterbury Tales General Prologue]</ref>
== Personal life ==
Brinkman is married to cognitive neuroscientist and television host [[H. A. Berlin|Dr. Heather Berlin]]. They have a daughter, Hannah, born in 2013, and a son, Dylan, born in 2016.<ref>[http://www.orlandomagazine.com/Orlando-Magazine/May-2015/Rap-Scholar/ Rap Scholar]</ref>
== Literature Rap ==
Brinkman first gained widespread media attention for his one-man show "The Rap Canterbury Tales," devised as a means of re-telling Chaucer's iconic stories for a modern audience.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts-reviews/the-rap-canterbury-tales/2007/10/04/1191091243627.html Melbourne Age Article “The Rap Canterbury Tales Review”]</ref><ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2006/dec/25/entertainment/et-chaucer25 Los Angeles Times Article “Yo, just call him Chaucer’s homie”]</ref> The show premiered at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 2004, and the following year Brinkman was sponsored by [[Cambridge University]] to perform the show in British secondary schools.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/4721073.stm BBC News Article “Chaucer’s Tales Become Rap Songs]</ref> The Rap Canterbury Tales was published as an illustrated paperback by Talon Books in 2006.<ref>[http://talonbooks.com/books/the-rap-canterbury-tales Talon Books Website]</ref>
Brinkman's 2010 follow-up show, "Rapconteur," premiered at the Edinburgh [[Free Fringe]] and featured hip hop adaptations of [[Beowulf]], the [[Epic of Gilgamesh]], and the Finnish [[Kalevala]].<ref>[http://www.bababrinkman.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/Rapconteur-Review-The-Scotsman.pdf Scotsman Article “Rapconteur Review”]</ref><ref>[http://broadwaybaby.com/shows/rapconteur/21051 Broadway Baby Article “Rapconteur Review”]</ref><ref>[http://www.whatsonstage.com/edinburgh-theatre/reviews/08-2010/rapconteur_12076.html What’s On Stage Article “Rapconteur Review”]</ref>
In 2011, Brinkman premiered "The Canterbury Tales Remixed" at the Soho Playhouse in [[New York City]].<ref>[https://www.backstage.com/review/ny-theater/off-broadway/the-canterbury-tales-remixed/ Backstage Article “Canterbury Tales Remixed Review”]</ref> The show combined material from Rapconteur with new adaptations of [[The Merchant's Tale]], [[The Pardoner's Tale]], and [[The Wife of Bath's Tale]] and was released as a full-length album in 2012.<ref>[http://laughingsquid.com/the-canterbury-tales-remixed-album-released/ Laughing Squid Article “The Canterbury Tales Remixed Album has Been Released”]</ref>
Because of his interest in merging hip-hop and classic literature, Brinkman has referred to his style of rap as "[[Lit Hop]]," which was also the title of his 2006 solo rap album.<ref>[https://thetyee.ca/Music/2007/03/01/MusicPicks/ The Tyee Article “Listen to This!”]</ref>
== Science Rap ==
In 2008, Brinkman was commissioned to write a new rap show about [[evolution]] by Professor [[Mark Pallen]], [[microbiologist]] and author of The [[Rough Guides|Rough Guide]] to Evolution. The result was "The Rap Guide to Evolution," a hip hop homage to [[Charles Darwin]] which Brinkman first performed in Britain for the Darwin [[Anniversary|bicentennial]] in February 2009.<ref>http://blogs.sciencemag.org/origins/2009/02/rapping-with-darwin-and-dawkin.html</ref> Because the lyrics were fact-checked for scientific accuracy, Professor Pallen calls it "the first [[peer review|peer-reviewed]] rap".<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/28/science/28rap.html?_r=2</ref> Brinkman cites [[Richard Dawkins]], [[David Sloan Wilson]], [[Jared Diamond]], [[Geoffrey Miller (psychologist)|Geoffrey Miller]], and [[E. O. Wilson]] as his influences in writing the show.
The Rap Guide to Evolution premiered at the 2009 Edinburgh Festival Fringe, winning a Fringe First Award from [[The Scotsman]] for best new theatre writing.<ref>http://www.edinburgh-festivals.com/viewpreview.aspx?id=670</ref> In 2010 the UK's largest biomedical charity, the [[Wellcome Trust]], provided grant funding for Brinkman to make a series of educational music videos based on the show, as a resource for biology teachers.<ref>http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/2011/News/WTVM051468.htm</ref> The Rap Guide to Evolution completed a five-month [[Off-Broadway]] theatre run in November 2011,<ref>http://theater.nytimes.com/2011/06/28/theater/reviews/baba-brinkman-in-rap-guide-at-soho-playhouse-review.html</ref> for which Brinkman received a 2012 [[Drama Desk Award]] nomination for [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding One-Person Show|Outstanding Solo Performance]], losing to Irish actor [[Cillian Murphy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dramadeskawards.com/2012-nominees.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120816020115/http://www.dramadeskawards.com/2012-nominees.html |archivedate=2012-08-16 }}</ref>
Brinkman has performed selections from The Rap Guide to Evolution on [[The Rachel Maddow Show]]<ref>http://www.nbcnews.com/id/37449161/ns/msnbc-rachel_maddow_show/t/rachel-maddow-show-friday-may-th/</ref> and at the Seattle Science Festival, sharing the stage with [[Jurassic Park (film)|Jurassic Park]] palaeontologist [[Jack Horner (paleontologist)|Jack Horner]] and British physicist [[Stephen Hawking]].<ref>http://o.seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/thearts/2018385919_science09.html</ref>
In 2010 Brinkman produced a "Rationalist Anthem" called "Off That," attacking various forms of [[pseudoscience]]. The song was inspired by the [[Jay Z]] track of the same name, which is featured on [[The Blueprint 3]] album. The video for Brinkman's unauthorized remix was released as part of an online science music festival called [[Geek Pop]]<ref>http://geekpop.co.uk/2010/03/20/off-that-video-exclusive-from-baba-brinkman/</ref> and was popular with atheist blogs.<ref>http://www.patheos.com/blogs/friendlyatheist/2010/03/20/off-that-the-rationalist-anthem/</ref><ref>http://40yearoldatheist.com/baba-brinkman-rationalizn-darwin-testifyin-make-ya-think-bout-evolutionizn-rapper/2010/05/</ref>
Brinkman followed up his Darwin tribute with a sequel show specifically about [[evolutionary psychology]], "The Rap Guide to Human Nature," which premiered at the Edinburgh Fringe in 2010.<ref>http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/edinburgh_fringe_2010/r/18278/the_rap_guide_to_human_nature/review</ref> The album features "peer review" phone messages from [[David Buss]], [[Olivia Judson]], and [[David Sloan Wilson]] commenting on the science content in Brinkman's lyrics.<ref>http://music.bababrinkman.com/album/the-rap-guide-to-human-nature</ref> In 2012 "Human Nature" was adapted into a theatre production, "Ingenious Nature," which ran off-Broadway from November 2012 through January 2013.<ref>http://bigstory.ap.org/article/review-dj-baba-brinkman-mixes-darwin-and-dating</ref>
In March 2012, Brinkman was announced as a songwriter-in-residence at the [[National Institute for Mathematical and Biological Synthesis]] (NIMBioS) and spent a month at the [[University of Tennessee Knoxville]] as a guest of the Institute, along with DJ and music producer [[Jamie Simmonds]].<ref>[http://www.nimbios.org/wordpress/2012/03/23/nimbios-announces-new-songwriter-in-residence-baba-brinkman/ NIMBioS “Baba Brinkman Announced as Songwriter-in-Residence]</ref> Brinkman later released "The Infomatic EP," a collection of hip-hop songs inspired by [[computational biology]].<ref>[http://www.bcmusicianmag.com/baba-brinkman-bcs-raconteur/ BC Musician Magazine Article “Baba Brinkman – BC’s Raconteur”]</ref>
Brinkman's next play, "Rap Guide to Religion," premiered at the 2014 Edinburgh Fringe,<ref>[http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/baba-brinkman-gilded-balloon-10540 British Theatre Guide “The Rap Guide to Religion”]</ref> before transferring to the Soho Playhouse for an off-Broadway run in October 2014. The production ran for seven months and was a Time Out New York<ref>http://www.timeout.com/newyork/things-to-do/the-rap-guide-to-religion</ref> and New York Times Critics' Pick, as well as receiving a 2015 Drama Desk Award nomination in the category "[[Drama Desk Award for Unique Theatrical Experience|Unique Theatrical Experience]]".<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/17/theater/review-rap-guide-to-religion-examines-why-humanity-created-god.html?_r=0 New York Times Article “Rap Guide to Religion”]</ref> The show explores theories from the [[cognitive science of religion]] and promotes [[religious naturalism]], prompting [[American Humanist Association]] magazine to refer to Brinkman as "atheism's best salesman".<ref>[http://thehumanist.com/arts_entertainment/theater/atheisms-best-salesman The Humanist Article “Atheism’s Best Salesman”]</ref>
In 2015, Brinkman was commissioned by [[Arizona State University]] and [[Randolph M. Nesse|Dr. Randolph Nesse]] to write and produce an album entitled "The Rap Guide to Medicine", which communicates themes from [[evolutionary medicine]]. Dr. Nesse said of the finished project: "This is amazing. I won't need to teach my course, I'll just have students listen to the album!"<ref>[https://evmed.asu.edu/news/center-evolution-medicine-partners-artist-produce-peer-reviewed-rap ASU Center for Evolution and Medicine Article “Peer Reviewed Rap”]</ref> The album includes songs about [[Mendelian disease]], [[parasitology]], [[somatic evolution in cancer]], [[mismatch theory]], and [[senescence]].<ref>[http://rapguidetomedicine.com Baba Brinkman “The Rap Guide to Medicine”]</ref>
In 2014 and 2016, Brinkman attended the [[Toward a Science of Consciousness|Science of Consciousness]] conference in Tucson, AZ, performing a "Rap Up" or daily rap summary of the conference talks on [[Neuroscience]] and [[Philosophy of Mind]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/17/science/science-of-consciousness-conference-raw-data.html New York Times Article “Science of Consciousness Conference”]</ref> Computational neuroscientist [[Anil Seth]] saw Brinkman's performances and proposed they collaborate on a new show about the neuroscience of consciousness.<ref>[http://www.sussex.ac.uk/broadcast/read/40168 University of Sussex Press Release]</ref> Brinkman premiered "Rap Guide to Consciousness" at the 2017 [[Brighton Fringe]], [[Winnipeg Fringe]] and Edinburgh Fringe to critical acclaim.<ref>[http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/culture/theatre/fringe-interview-baba-brinkman-on-the-canadian-fringe-circuit-1-4506768 The Scotsman Fringe Interview]</ref><ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/arts/baba-brinkman-comedy-review-comedy-hip-hop-and-neuroscience-will-make-your-brain-buzz-a3623511.html Evening Standard Review of Rap Guide to Consciousness]</ref><ref>[http://broadwaybaby.com/shows/baba-brinkmans-rap-guide-to-consciousness/719920 Broadway Baby Review of Rap Guide to Consciousness]</ref> The show explores several neurobiological theories of consciousness, including [[Global Workspace Theory]], [[Integrated Information Theory]], and [[Predictive Coding]], as well as the [[Philosophical Zombie]], [[Free Will]], [[Materialism]], and [[Memetics]].<ref>[http://music.bababrinkman.com/album/the-rap-guide-to-consciousness Baba Brinkman “The Rap Guide to Consciousness”]</ref>
== Environment and Ecology Rap ==
Brinkman was commissioned by the [[WILD Foundation]] to produce "The Rap Guide to Wilderness" in 2014. The album was critically acclaimed and features songs about [[biodiversity]], [[extinction]], [[conservation (ethic)|conservation]], [[habitat loss]] and [[trophic cascade]].<ref>[http://music.bababrinkman.com/album/the-rap-guide-to-wilderness Baba Brinkman “The Rap Guide to Wilderness”]</ref><ref>[http://www.wild.org/blog/the-rap-guide-to-wilderness-connecting-people-to-nature-with-music/ Wild Foundation Article]</ref><ref>[https://www.audubon.org/news/review-rap-guide-wilderness Audubon Article “Rap Guide to Wilderness Review”]</ref><ref>[http://www.technicianonline.com/features/article_4c6f0db2-9a18-11e4-af9f-bba6b16570b9.html Technician Online Article “The Rap Guide to Wilderness]</ref><ref>[http://www.mnn.com/lifestyle/arts-culture/blogs/rap-guide-to-wilderness-gives-advocacy-a-new-beat#ixzz3M4aaAtKi Mother Nature Network Article]</ref>
In 2015 Brinkman's play "Rap Guide to Climate Chaos" premiered at the Edinburgh Fringe,<ref>[https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2015/rap-guide-climate-chaos/ The Stage “Climate Chaos” Review]</ref><ref>[http://www.wow247.co.uk/2015/08/24/theatre-review-rap-guide-to-climate-chaos/ Scotsman “Climate Chaos” Theatre Review]</ref><ref>[http://www.theskinny.co.uk/festivals/edinburgh-fringe/comedy/george-egg-rap-guide-climate-chaos-review The Skinny “Climate Chaos” Review]</ref> followed by performances at the [[COP21]] United Nations Climate Change Conference.<ref>[http://observer.com/2016/01/meet-the-guy-raising-awareness-about-climate-change-through-hip-hop/ New York Observer “Meet the Guy Raising Awareness About Climate Change Through Hip Hop]</ref> "Climate Chaos" went on to play off-Broadway for six months in 2016, and featured [[Michael E. Mann]], [[Gavin Schmidt]], [[Naomi Oreskes]] and [[Bill Nye]] as talkback speakers.<ref>[https://www.popsci.com/rap-guide-to-climate-chaos Popular Science Article “Rap Guide to Climate Chaos Review”]</ref><ref>[http://pataphysicalscience.blogspot.com/2016/03/q-with-rap-artist-baba-brinkman.html Pataphysical Science “Q&A with Baba Brinkman”]</ref> Bill Nye also features on the album version of "Climate Chaos", rapping the chorus of the track "What's Beef", which remixes a [[Notorious B.I.G.]] song to discuss [[climate change denial]].<ref>[http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/10/bill-nye-the-science-guy-baba-brinkman-whats-beef/ XXL Magazine “Bill Nye the Science Guy Raps on Baba Brinkman’s ‘What’s Beef’”]</ref> "Rap Guide to Climate Chaos" summarizes the science, politics, and economics of [[climate change]] and advocates for a global [[carbon tax]] as part of the solution.<ref>[https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/climate-change-rap-baba-brinkman_us_5717baa3e4b024dae4f0bae1 Huffington Post Article “This Guy Raps About Climate Change, and Bill Nye Loves Him”]</ref>
In 2016, after the election of [[Donald Trump]], Brinkman worked with [[Wesleyan University]] professor [[Gary Yohe]], a senior contributor to the [[IPCC]] and co-recipient along with [[Al Gore]] of the 2007 [[Nobel Peace Prize]], to produce a new song and video entitled "Erosion", summarizing data from the [[National Climate Assessment]] on the US-based physical impacts of climate change.<ref>[http://newsletter.blogs.wesleyan.edu/2017/01/20/rapguidetoclimatechaos/ Wesleyan Newsletter on Gary Yohe and Baba Brinkman]</ref><ref>[https://medium.com/defiant/this-canadian-rapper-schooled-trump-on-climate-science-3600ce0cd72a Medium Article “This Canadian Rapper Schooled Trump on Climate Science”]</ref>
== Science Comedy ==
Brinkman and his wife, the neuroscientist Dr. Heather Berlin, co-wrote and performed in a science comedy variety show entitled "Off The Top" at the Edinburgh Fringe in 2014, 2015, and 2017 about the neuroscience of improvisation and freestyle rap.<ref>http://mumblecomedy.net/2015/08/18/baba-brinkman-and-heather-berlin-off-the-top/</ref><ref>http://www.artsawardvoice.com/magazine/reviews/Off-The-Top</ref><ref>http://www.broadwaybaby.com/shows/off-the-top/707288</ref>
== Controversy ==
The Rap Guide to Evolution won the National Center for Science Education's 2013 Friend of Darwin Award.<ref>http://ncse.com/evolution/rap-artist-education-advisor-extraordinaire-master-scientist</ref> The show is controversial primarily for its open criticism of creationism and the essentialist elements of its discussion of natural selection.<ref>http://williamsrecord.com/2013/02/13/baba-brinkman-entertains-but-not-without-discomfort/</ref> Teachers have also expressed concern about Brinkman's use of strong language and anti-religious sentiments in his educational performances and videos.<ref>http://rapguidetoevolution.co.uk/concerned-teachers</ref>
Brinkman himself has been described as an "evangelical atheist"<ref>http://www.edinburgh-festivals.com/viewpreview.aspx?id=1842</ref> and has blogged about his encounters with creationists, both in educational settings<ref>http://www.bababrinkman.com/tennessee-monkey-trials/</ref> and within his own family.<ref>http://www.bababrinkman.com/communicating-evolution-via-creationist-cousins/</ref> He also performed in support of the [[Military Association of Atheists & Freethinkers]] "Rock Beyond Belief" concert alongside Richard Dawkins at Fort Bragg, NC in 2012.<ref>http://rockbeyondbelief.com/2011/02/08/rapper-baba-brinkman-joins-lineup-supports-foxhole-atheists/</ref>
Ingenious Nature was reviewed unfavourably, and Brinkman received criticism for "singling out women in the audience, pointing at them, and rapping about their ovulation cycles," among other things.<ref>http://www.backstage.com/review/ny-theater/off-broadway/baba-brinkman-ingenious-nature-soho-playhouse/</ref>
The song "Tranquility Bank" from The Rap Guide to Wilderness received a hostile response from some environmentalists because of its assertion that urban living is better for the environment than [[back-to-the-land movement]]s.<ref>http://www.samaritanmag.com/musicians/baba-brinkman-offends-some-people-rap-guide-wilderness</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in Turkmenistan''' begins before [[Russia]]n advances into the region when the area was under the influence of [[Persia]].<ref name="turkm">{{Cite web| last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = Turkmenistan | work = Draft for "A Short Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith" | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_turkmenistan | accessdate = 2008-05-23}}</ref> By 1887 a community of [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]] refugees from [[religious violence]] in Persia had made a religious center in [[Ashgabat]].<ref name="turkm"/> Shortly afterwards — by 1894 — Russia made [[Turkmenistan]] part of the [[Russian Empire]].<ref name="russia">{{Cite web| last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = Russia | work = Draft for "A Short Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith" | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_russia | accessdate = 2008-04-14}}</ref> While the Bahá'í Faith spread across the [[Russian Empire]]<ref name="russia"/><ref name="statement">{{Cite web|author=Local Spiritual Assembly of Kyiv |title=Statement on the history of the Bahá'í Faith in Soviet Union |work=Official Website of the Bahá'ís of Kyiv |publisher=Local Spiritual Assembly of Kyiv |year=2007–8 |url=http://bahai.kiev.ua/history9.html |accessdate=2008-04-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715093037/http://bahai.kiev.ua/history9.html |archivedate=15 July 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> and attracted the attention of scholars and artists,<ref name="oneworld">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Tolstoy, Leo |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |page=340 |isbn= 1-85168-184-1}}</ref> the Bahá'í community in Ashgabat built the first [[Bahá'í House of Worship]], elected one of the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly|local administrative institutions]] and was a center of scholarship. During the Soviet period religious persecution made the Bahá'í community almost disappear — however, Bahá'ís who moved into the regions in the 1950s did identify individuals still adhering to the religion. Following the dissolution of the [[Soviet Union]] in late 1991, Bahá'í communities and their administrative bodies started to develop across the nations of the former Soviet Union;<ref name="euro">{{Cite news| last = Hassall | first = Graham | last2 = Fazel | first2 = Seena | title = 100 Years of the Bahá'í Faith in Europe | periodical = Bahá’í Studies Review | issue = 8 | pages = 35–44 | volume = 1998 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_fazel_100-years_europe | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> In 1994 [[Turkmenistan]] elected its own National Spiritual Assembly<ref name = "notes">{{Cite web| last = Hassall | first = Graham |author2=Universal House of Justice | title = National Spiritual Assemblies statistics 1923-1999 | work = Assorted Resource Tools | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | accessdate = 2008-04-02 }}</ref> however, laws passed in 1995 in Turkmenistan required 500 adult religious adherents in each locality for registration and no Bahá'í community in Turkmenistan could meet this requirement.<ref name="turk">{{Cite web | last = compiled by Wagner | first = Ralph D. | title = Turkmenistan | work = Synopsis of References to the Bahá'í Faith, in the US State Department's Reports on Human Rights 1991-2000 | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url = http://bahai-library.com/documents/hr/hr-turkmenistan.htm | accessdate = 2008-05-25}}</ref> As of 2007 the religion had still failed to reach the minimum number of adherents to register<ref name="notreg">{{Cite web | author = U.S. State Department | title = Turkmenistan - International Religious Freedom Report 2007 | publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair | date = 14 September 2007 | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90236.htm | accessdate = 2008-05-21}}</ref> and individuals have had their homes raided for [[Bahá'í literature]].<ref name="raided">{{Cite news | last = Corley | first = Felix | author-link = Felix Corley | title = TURKMENISTAN: Religious communities theoretically permitted, but attacked in practice? | newspaper = F18News | date = 1 April 2004 | url = http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=293 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref>
==History in the region==
=== Community of Ashgabat=== [[File:Ashkabad Temple Bahai.jpg|thumb|150px|left|The first Bahá'í House of Worship was built in [[Ashgabat]].]] The Bahá'í community of [[Ashgabat]] (also spelled `Ishqábád, Ashkhabad) was founded in about 1884, mostly from religious refugees from Persia.<ref name="ashg">{{Cite book | last = Momen | first = Moojan | authorlink = Moojan Momen |author2=ed. Shirin Akiner | title = Cultural Change and Continuity in Central Asia, Chapter - The Bahá'í Community of Ashkhabad; it's social basis and importance in Bahá'í History | publisher = Kegan Paul International | year = 1991 | location = London | pages = 278–305. | url = http://www.northill.demon.co.uk/relstud/ishqabad.htm | isbn = 0-7103-0351-3}}</ref> One of the most prominent members of the community was [[Mirza Abu'l-Fadl|Mirza Abu'l-Fadl Gulpaygani]], an [[Apostles of Bahá'u'lláh|Apostle of Bahá'u'lláh]], who lived in Ashgabat off and on from 1889 to 1894. A short time after moving there, the assassination of one of the Bahá'ís there, [[Haji Muhammad Rida Isfahani]] occurred and Gulpaygani helped the Bahá'í community to respond to this event and later he was the spokesman for the Bahá'ís at the trial of the assassins. This event established the independence of the Bahá'í Faith from [[Islam]] both for the Russian government and for the people of Ashgabat.<ref name="momen">{{Cite web|last=Momen |first=Moojan |title=Abu'l-Fadl Gulpaygani, Mirza |work=Draft for "A Short Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith" |publisher=Scholar's Official Website of Articles |url=http://www.northill.demon.co.uk/relstud/abulfadl.htm |accessdate=2008-05-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513090142/http://www.northill.demon.co.uk/relstud/abulfadl.htm |archivedate=13 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Under the protection and freedom given by the Russian authorities, the number of Bahá'ís in the community rose to 4,000 (1,000 children) by 1918 and for the first time anywhere in the world a true Bahá'í community was established, with its own hospitals, schools, workshops, newspapers,<ref name="azer">{{Citation|last=Balci |first=Bayram |last2=Jafarov |first2=Azer |title=The Baha’is of the Caucasus: From Russian Tolerance to Soviet Repression {2/3} |newspaper=Caucaz.com |pages= |date=21 February 2007 |url=http://www.caucaz.com/home_eng/breve_contenu.php?id=300 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524000119/http://www.caucaz.com/home_eng/breve_contenu.php?id=300 |archivedate=24 May 2011 }}</ref><ref name="DEV">{{cite magazine | title = Shining example Cradle of Faith |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1987|pages=8–11| url = | issue = 675| issn = 0195-9212}}</ref> cemetery, and House of Worship.<ref name="momen"/> The city population was between 44 and 50 thousand at this time.<ref name="ashg"/>
This first [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] was constructed inside the city of Ashgabat. The design of the building was started in 1902, and the construction was completed in 1908; it was supervised by [[Vakílu'd-Dawlih]],<ref name="iranica">{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= Encyclopædia Iranica |year= 1989 |article=Bahai temples | first = V. | last = Rafati |author2=Sahba, F.}}</ref> another Apostle of Bahá'u'lláh. The House of Worship in Ashgabat has been the only Bahá'í House of Worship thus far to have the humanitarian subsidiaries associated with the institution built alongside it.<ref name="us_ashkabad">{{Cite web|title=Baha'i House of Worship - Ashkabad, Central Asia |url=http://www.bahai.us/bahai-temple-ashkabad |accessdate=2007-08-03 |year=2007 |publisher=The National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the United States |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808220600/http://www.bahai.us/bahai-temple-ashkabad |archivedate=8 August 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
===Community of Merv=== The city of [[Merv]] (also spelled Marv, Mary) had a Bahá'í community, while it was far smaller and less developed. The Bahá'í community in the city received permission to build a House of Worship which they did on a smaller scale.<ref name="turkm"/><ref name="DEV"/>
===Soviet period=== By the time the effects of the [[October Revolution]] began to spread across the Russian Empire transforming it into the [[Soviet Union]], Bahá'ís had spread<ref name="iranica" /> east through [[Central Asia]] and [[Caucasus]], and also north into [[Moscow]], [[Leningrad]], [[Tbilisi]]<ref name="hist">{{Cite web|author=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Azerbaijan |title=Baha'i Faith History in Azerbaijan |work= |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Azerbaijan |url=http://www.bahai.az/lib/articles/histofaz/history_en.shtml |doi= |accessdate=2008-12-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219032306/http://www.bahai.az/lib/articles/histofaz/history_en.shtml |archivedate=19 February 2012 }}</ref> and [[Kazan]] with the community of Ashgabat alone numbering about 3000 adults. After the October Revolution the Ashgabat Bahá'í community was progressively severed from the rest of the worldwide Bahá'í community.<ref name="iranica" /> In 1924 Bahá'ís in Merv had schools and a special committee for the advancement of women.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Foreign Bahá'í News |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July–August 1925 | page =7| url = | issue = 6}}</ref> Initially the religion still grew in organization when the election of the regional National Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the Caucasus and Turkistan in 1925.<ref name="hassall-Rus">{{Cite journal | last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Notes on the Babi and Baha'i Religions in Russia and its territories | journal = The Journal of Bahá'í Studies | volume = 05 | issue = 3 | year = 1993 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_babi_bahai_russia | accessdate = 2008-06-01}}</ref>
However, the Bahá'í House of Worship was expropriated by the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] authorities in 1928, the Bahá'í schools had been closed in 1930,<ref name="DEV"/> and the House of Worship was leased back to the Bahá'ís until 1938 when it was fully secularized by the communist government and turned into an [[art museum|art gallery]]. The records of events shows an increasing hostility to the Bahá'is between 1928 and 1938.<ref name="events">{{Cite journal| title = Survey of Current Baha'i Activities in the East and West: Persecution and Deportation of the Baha'is of Caucasus and Turkistan | journal = The Baha'i World |volume = VIII | issue = 1938–40 | pages = 87–90 | publisher = Wilmette: Baha'i Publishing Committee | year = 1942 | url = | doi = | id = | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> From 1928 free rent was set for five years, and the Bahá'ís were asked to make certain repairs, which they did. But in 1933, before the five-year rent agreement expired the government suddenly decided expensive renovations would be required. These unexpected requirements were accomplished, but in 1934 complaints about the condition of the building were again laid. Inquires from abroad silenced the complaints. In 1936 escalated demands were made beyond the resources of the local community. The Bahá'ís of Turkistan and the Caucasus rallied and were able to sustain the construction requested. Then the government made moves to confiscate the main gardens of the property to provide for a playground of a school (the school itself being confiscated from the Bahá'ís originally) which would wall off the grounds from the Bahá'ís — leaving only an entrance to the temple through a side entrance rather than the main entrance facing the front of the property. Protests lead to the abandonment of this plan; then in 1938 all pretexts came to an end.<ref name="events"/>
The [[1948 Ashgabat earthquake]] seriously damaged the building and rendered it unsafe; the heavy rains of the following years weakened the structure. It was demolished in 1963 and the site converted into a public park.<ref name="iranica" /> With the Soviet ban on religion, the Bahá'ís, strictly adhering to their principle of obedience to legal government, abandoned its administration and its properties were nationalized.<ref>{{Cite book| last = Effendi | first = Shoghi | authorlink = Shoghi Effendi | title = The World Order of Bahá'u'lláh | publisher = US Bahá’í Publishing Trust, 1991 first pocket-size edition | date = 11 March 1936 | location = Haifa, Palestine | pages = 64–67 | url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/wob-34.html#pg64| isbn = }}</ref> By 1938, with the [[NKVD]] (Soviet secret police) and the [[Religion in the Soviet Union#Policy toward religions in practice|policy of religious oppression]] most Bahá'ís were sent to prisons and camps or abroad; Bahá'í communities in 38 cities ceased to exist. In the case of Ashgabat, Bahá'í sources indicate<ref name="events"/> on 5 February the members of the assembly, leaders of the community and some general members of the community to a total of 500 people were arrested, homes were searched and all records and literature were confiscated (claiming they were working for the advantage of foreigners), and sometimes forced to dig their own graves as part of the interrogation. It is believed one woman set fire to herself and died later in a hospital. The women and children were largely exiled to Iran. In 1953 Bahá'ís started to move to the [[Soviet Republics]] in Asia, after the head of the religion at the time, [[Shoghi Effendi]], initiated a plan called the [[Ten Year Crusade]]. The Bahá'ís who moved to Turkmenistan found some individual Bahá'ís living there though the religion remained unorganized.<ref name="russia"/><ref>{{Cite book| last = Effendi | first = Shoghi | authorlink = Shoghi Effendi | title = Citadel of Faith | publisher = US Bahá’í Publishing Trust, 1980 third printing | orig-year = collected letters from 1947-57 | location = Haifa, Palestine |page=107 | url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/CF/cf-9.html#pg107 | isbn = }}</ref> During the 1978-9 civil war in [[Afghanistan]] some Bahá'ís fled to Turkmenistan.<ref>{{Cite web | author = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Afghanistan | title = Bahá'í Faith in Afghanistan… A short History of Afghan Bahá'ís | work = Official Website of the Bahá'ís of Afghanistan | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Afghanistan | year = 2008 | url = http://www.afghanbahais.org/afghanbahais.htm#ENg | accessdate = 2008-05-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080626223447/http://www.afghanbahais.org/afghanbahais.htm| archivedate= 26 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[File:Turkmenistan-map.png|thumb|340px|Map of Turkmenistan]]
The first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] in the Soviet Union was elected in Ashgabat, Turkmenistan, when conditions permitted it in 1989; 61 Bahá'ís were listed as eligible for election. The Local Spiritual Assembly was officially registered by the city council of Ashgabat on 31 January 1990. Through the rest of 1990 several Local Spiritual Assemblies formed across the Soviet Union including [[Moscow]], [[Ulan-Ude]], [[Kazan]], [[Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk]], [[Leningrad]], and [[Murmansk]].<ref name="euro"/> In September 1990, 26 Baha'is gathered together for the election of the first Local Spiritual Assembly of [[Merv]].<ref name="turkm"/> By September 1991, there were some 800 known Baha'is and 23 Local Spiritual Assemblies across the dissolving Soviet Union,<ref name="russia"/> while in Turkmenistan there were about 125 Bahá'ís with two Local Assemblies and two groups (in [[Balakhanih]] and [[Bayranali]]). When the National Spiritual Assembly of the Soviet Union was dissolved in 1992, a regional National Spiritual Assembly for the whole of Central Asia (Turkmenistan, [[Kazakhstan]], [[Kirgizia]], [[Tajikistan]], and [[Uzbekistan]]) was formed with its seat in Ashgabat. Most of these countries went on to form their own National Spiritual Assembly,<ref name="turkm"/> and their communities went on to flourish (see [[Bahá'í Faith in Kazakhstan]].)
==Banned community== Since its inception, the religion has had involvement in [[Socio-economic development (Bahá'í)|socio-economic development]] — beginning by giving greater freedom to women.<ref name="iranhistory">{{Cite web| last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | format = | doi =| accessdate = 2009-10-16}}</ref> promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,<ref>{{Cite journal| last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }}</ref> That involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics.<ref name="iranhistory"/> The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.<ref>{{Cite journal|title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}}</ref> Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities where they lived. World-wide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. As the environment of [[Perestroika]] took hold across the Soviet Block, the Bahá'í community of Ashgabat was the first to re-form its Local Spiritual Assembly following the oppressive decades of Soviet rule, had doubled its numbers from 1989 to 1991, and had successfully registered with the city government of Ashgabat.
However, the nation of Turkmenistan revised its religious registration laws such that, in 1995, 500 adult religious adherent citizens were required in each locality for a religious community to be registered.<ref name="turk"/> Thus by 1997 the Bahá'ís were unregistered by the government along with several other religious communities.<ref>{{Cite news | author-link = Amnesty International | title = TURKMENISTAN - Harassment and imprisonment of religious believers | work = | publisher = Amnesty International | date = 1 March 2000 | url = http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/3b83b7047.html | accessdate = 2010-11-10}}</ref> More than just being unable to form administrative institutions, own properties like temples, and publish literature, perform scholarly work and community service projects — their membership in a religion is simply unrecognized: The religion is considered banned,<ref>{{Cite news | last = Corley | first = Felix | author-link = Felix Corley | title = TURKMENISTAN: Religious freedom survey, April 2004 | newspaper = F18News | date = 7 April 2004 | url = http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=296 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> and homes are raided for Bahá'í literature.<ref name="raided"/> As of 2007, under these harsh conditions, the Bahá'í community in Turkmenistan was unable to reach the required number of adult believers to be recognized by the government as a religion.<ref name="notreg"/> The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated some 1000 Bahá'ís across Turkmenistan in 2005.<ref name="WCE-05">{{Cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-04}}</ref>
==See also== *[[History of Turkmenistan]] *[[Religion in Turkmenistan]] *[[Freedom of religion in Turkmenistan]] *[[Bahá'í Faith in Azerbaijan]] *[[Bahá'í Faith in Georgia]] *[[Bahá'í Faith in Uzbekistan]]

page.title: Banishment of Buddhist monks from Nepal

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.4)
revision.text:
[[File:Mahapragya exiled 1926 wk.jpg|175px|thumb|The group of five Buddhist monks exiled in 1926.]] [[File:Nepalese Buddhist monks in Kalimpong in circa 1935..jpg|175px|thumb|Pragyananda, Mahapragya and Shakyananda in Kalimpong in circa 1935.]] [[File:Dhammalok mahasthavir.jpg|175px|thumb|Dhammalok, expelled in 1944.]] The '''banishment of Buddhist monks from Nepal''' was part of a government campaign to suppress the resurgence of [[Theravada|Theravada Buddhism]] in [[Nepal]] in the early decades of the 20th century. There were two deportations of [[bhikkhu|monks]] from [[Kathmandu]], in 1926 and 1944.
The exiled monks were the first group of monks to be seen in Nepal since the [[14th century]]. They were at the forefront of a movement to revive [[Theravada|Theravada Buddhism]], which had disappeared from the country more than five hundred years ago. The tyrannical [[Rana dynasty]] disapproved of Buddhism and the [[Newar language]]. It saw the activities of the monks and their growing following as a threat. When police harassment and imprisonment failed to deter the monks, all of whom were [[Newars]], they were deported.
Among the charges made against them were preaching a new faith, converting [[Hindu]]s, encouraging women to renounce and thereby undermining family life and writing books in Newari.<ref>LeVine, Sarah and Gellner, David N. (2005). ''Rebuilding Buddhism: The Theravada Movement in Twentieth-Century Nepal.'' Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|0-674-01908-3}}, {{ISBN|978-0-674-01908-9}}. Page 48.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lumbini.org.uk/bd_n_thera_t.html|title=Theravada Buddhism in Modern Nepal |publisher=Lumbini Nepalese Buddha Dharma Society (UK)|accessdate=9 May 2013|date= }}</ref>
==Expulsion of 1926==
In 1926, five monks along with their Tibetan guru Tsering Norbu were expelled from the country. These five monks, whose [[Dharma name]]s were [[Bauddha Rishi Mahapragya]], Mahaviryya, Mahachandra, Mahakhanti and Mahagnana, had been ordained under the [[Tibetan Buddhism|Tibetan Buddhist]] tradition.
The government objected to Mahapragya, who was born a [[Hindu]], converting to [[Buddhism]] and the monks making alms rounds in Kathmandu. The police arrested the monks and jailed and questioned them. The case went up to the prime minister, [[Chandra Shumsher JBR]], who ordered their banishment. They were given a few days to beg for provisions under the condition that they return to the police station to sleep. Then they were marched to the Indian border under police escort. The five monks and their teacher first went to [[Bodh Gaya]], [[India]], from where they scattered, some of them going to [[Burma]] and [[Tibet]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Dietrich |first=Angela |title=Buddhist Monks and Rana Rulers: A History of Persecution |url=http://ccbs.ntu.edu.tw/FULLTEXT/JR-BH/bh117536.htm |accessdate=17 March 2011 |newspaper=Buddhist Himalaya: A Journal of Nagarjuna Institute of Exact Methods |year=1996 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001124156/http://ccbs.ntu.edu.tw/FULLTEXT/JR-BH/bh117536.htm |archivedate=1 October 2013 }}</ref>
==Expulsion of 1944==
In 1944, another group of eight monks were sent into exile. Their [[Dharma name]]s were [[Pragyananda Mahasthavir]], [[Dhammalok Mahasthavir]], [[Subodhananda|Subhodhananda]], Pragyarashmi, Pragyarasa, Ratnajyoti, Agga Dhamma and [[Kumar Kashyap Mahasthavir]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lumbini.org.uk/bd_n_thera_t.html |title=Theravada Buddhism in Modern Nepal |publisher=Lumbini Nepalese Buddha Dharma Society (UK)|accessdate=15 May 2013|date= }}</ref> This time they were accused of encouraging women to renounce and writing in [[Newar language|Newari.]] The monks were summoned before the prime minister [[Juddha Shumsher Jang Bahadur Rana|Juddha Shamsher Jang Bahadur Rana]] and ordered to sign a pledge that they would stop their activities. When they refused, they were ordered out of the country.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tuladhar|first=Kamal Ratna|title=The monks in yellow robes |url=http://www.ekantipur.com/2012/04/07/saturday-features/the-first-word--the-monks-in-yellow-robes/351932.html|accessdate=17 May 2013|newspaper=The Kathmandu Post|publisher= |date=7 April 2012}}</ref>
The monks went to [[Kushinagar]] and then [[Sarnath]] in India. There they founded Dharmodaya Sabha (Society for the Rise of the Teaching) which worked to promote Buddhism and published religious literature from exile. Some of the monks remained in [[India]] while others went to [[Tibet]], [[Bhutan]] and [[Sri Lanka]].<ref>{{cite book |last= Hilker |first= DS Kansakar |title= Syamukapu: The Lhasa Newars of Kalimpong and Kathmandu |url= |accessdate= |year=2005 |publisher= Vajra Publications |location= Kathmandu |isbn=99946-644-6-8 |page=58|chapter= Expulsion of Buddhist monks from Nepal}}</ref> [[Bhaju Ratna Kansakar]], a Nepalese merchant based in [[Kalimpong]], was one of their largest supporters in exile.
==Return from exile==
In 1946, a [[Sri Lanka|Sri Lankan]] goodwill mission visited [[Kathmandu]] and interceded on behalf of the monks. The delegation emphasized that Nepal was the birthplace of the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]], and that his followers should be free to practice their faith in the country where he was born. Subsequently, the ban was lifted and the monks returned and devoted themselves to spreading the faith with greater energy.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dietrich |first=Angela |title=Buddhist Monks and Rana Rulers: A History of Persecution |url=http://ccbs.ntu.edu.tw/FULLTEXT/JR-BH/bh117536.htm |accessdate=17 March 2011 |newspaper=Buddhist Himalaya: A Journal of Nagarjuna Institute of Exact Methods |year=1996 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001124156/http://ccbs.ntu.edu.tw/FULLTEXT/JR-BH/bh117536.htm |archivedate=1 October 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last= |first= |title=Boudddha Bhichhuharu |url=http://50.57.175.244:8001/xmlui/bitstream/10887/638/1/20030518.pdf |accessdate=12 May 2013 |newspaper=Gorkhapatra |date=3 September 1946 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Page 7.</ref>
In 1951, the Rana regime was ousted by a revolution and democracy established in Nepal. With democracy, overt persecution of Buddhists ended.<ref>{{cite web | last =Savada| first =Andrea Matles (ed.)| authorlink = | coauthors = | url = http://countrystudies.us/nepal/17.htm| title =The Return of the King| work = Nepal: A Country Study| publisher =Washington: GPO for the Library of Congress| year=1991| accessdate = 16 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1 =Panday | first1 =Tulsi Ram| last2 =Mishra | first2 =Surendra |last3 =Chemjong | first3 =Dambar |last4 =Pokhrel | first4 =Sanjeev |last5 =Rawal | first5 =Nabin |authorlink = | coauthors = | url = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001460/146086e.pdf| title =Forms and Patterns of Social Discrimination in Nepal| work =| publisher =UNESCO Kathmandu Office | page=67 |year=2006| accessdate = 16 May 2013}}</ref>

| units1 = unknown | units2 = unknown | units3 = | strength3 = | casualties1 = unknown | casualties2 = unknown | casualties3 = | notes = }} {{Campaignbox Early Mughal-Sikh Wars}} The '''Battle of Rohilla''' was a 1621 campaign by the [[Mughal Empire]] against the growing influence of the Sikhs.{{cite book|last=Jaques|first=Tony.|title=Dictionary of Battles and Sieges|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sbMFCZyAcnQC|accessdate=31 July 2010|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-33536-5|page=860}} Because of historic persecution from the [[Mughal Empire]], [[Guru Hargobind]] had militarized the Sikhs which resulted in increased political and military power. Thus he was attacked by a group of local jagirdars under the command of Abdul Khan. Local jagidar got killed by Rao Mandan Rathore and the rest of the army fled the field of battle resulting in a decisive Sikh victory.{{cite book|last=Jaques|first=Tony.|title=Dictionary of Battles and Sieges|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sbMFCZyAcnQC|accessdate=31 July 2010|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-33536-5|page=860}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord missing|Punjab (India)}} [[Category:Battles involving the Mughal Empire|Rohilla]] [[Category:Battles involving the Sikhs|Rohilla]] [[Category:1621 in India]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1621|Rohilla]] {{battle-stub}} {{Mughal-stub}} {{sikhism-stub}}

'''David Monongye''' was a [[Hopi]] [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] traditional leader (Kikmongwi of Hotevilla). Son of Yukiuma, keeper of the Fire Clan tablets, who founded Hotevilla in 1906. He is one of four Hopis (including [[Thomas Banyacya]], [[Dan Evehema]], and [[Dan Katchongva]]) who decided or were appointed to reveal Hopi traditional wisdom and teachings, including the Hopi prophecies for the future, to the general public in 1946, after the use of the first two nuclear weapons on Japan.
Monongye's age is uncertain.<ref name=l173>Loeffler 173</ref> He was alive in 1906 when Oraibi split into two villages,<ref name="friendlies">[http://billangelos.typepad.com/my_weblog/2010/01/mmm-chapter-five-part-two-friendlies-and-hostiles-in-hopiland.html "Chapter 6. The Last Hope, part 1."] ''Waking Up to Alzheimer's.'' (retrieved 28 Jan 2011)</ref> and lived to at least 1985, and at least 117.<ref>[http://www.petercoyote.com/news0907.html Peter Coyote notes that Monongye was in his 90s in 1972.]</ref>
In 1972, Monongye and three other Hopi elders participated in the [[United Nations Conference on the Human Environment]].<ref name=l173/> Monongye was a co-author of [http://www.jnanadana.org/hopi/techqua_ikachi_i.html Techqua Ikachi], the traditional Hopi newsletters produced from 1975 to 1986. Monongye inspired [[Godfrey Reggio]]'s 1982 film, [[Koyaanisqatsi]]: Life Out of Balance.<ref>Loeffler 33</ref> Monongye was vocal about problems generated by coal-mining on Hopi land.<ref>Willwerth, James. [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,924240-2,00.html "In Arizona: A New Long Walk?"] ''Time''. 30 Jun 1980 (retrieved 28 Jan 2011)</ref>

'''David J. Wolpe''' (born 1958) is the [[Max Webb]] Senior Rabbi of [[Sinai Temple (Los Angeles)|Sinai Temple]]. Named the most influential [[rabbi]] in America by ''[[Newsweek|Newsweek Magazine]]'' and one of the 50 most influential Jews in the world by the ''[[The Jerusalem Post|Jerusalem Post]]'', David Wolpe is the rabbi of [[Sinai Temple (Los Angeles)|Sinai Temple]] in Los Angeles, California. He previously taught at the [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America]] in New York, the [[American Jewish University]] in Los Angeles, [[Hunter College]], and [[UCLA]]. Wolpe’s work has been profiled in the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'', and he is a columnist for ''[http://time.com/author/rabbi-david-wolpe/ Time.com]'', he regularly writes for many publications, including ''[[Los Angeles Times|The LA Times]],'' the ''Washington Post’s On Faith website, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rabbi-david-wolpe/ The Huffington Post],'' and the ''[http://www.thejewishweek.com/editorial-opinion/musings New York Jewish Week]''. He has been on television numerous times, including the ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today Show]]'', ''Face the Nation'', ''ABC this Morning'', and ''[[CBS This Morning]]''. In addition, Wolpe has been featured in series on [[PBS]], [[A&E History Channel|A&E]], the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History channel]], and the [[Discovery Channel|Discovery channel]]. Wolpe is the author of eight books, including the national bestseller ''[http://www.penguin.com/author/david-j-wolpe/231465 Making Loss Matter: Creating Meaning in Difficult Times]''. Wolpe’s new book is titled ''[http://yalebooks.com/book/9780300188783/david David: The Divided Heart]''. It was a finalist for the [http://www.jewishbookcouncil.org/awards/2014-national-jewish-book-award-winners-and-finalists National Jewish Book Award (2014)], and has been optioned for a movie by Warner Bros.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/king-david-movie-in-the-works-at-warner-bros-1201338021/|title=‘King David’ Movie in the Works at Warner Bros.|last=McNary|first=Dave|website=Variety|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref>
Wolpe became the focus of international controversy when he gave a [[Passover]] [[Dvar Torah|sermon]] that questioned the historicity of [[the Exodus]] from [[Egypt]]. Ordained by the [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America]] in New York in 1987, Wolpe is a leader in [[Conservative Judaism]].
He is the brother of bioethicist [[Paul Root Wolpe]].
==Career== Wolpe has taught at the [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America]] in New York, and served as assistant to the Chancellor of that institution; at the [[University of Judaism]] (now the [[American Jewish University]]) in Los Angeles; and at [[Hunter College]] in New York. He frequently is featured on documentaries on Biblical topics produced by [[A&E Networks]] ([[A&E Network|A&E]], [[The Biography Channel]], [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] and [[History International|History Channel International]]). Wolpe has written a regular weekly column for the New York Jewish Week for almost 25 years. Wolpe's book, ''Why Faith Matters'', is both an answer to books about atheism and a recounting of his battle with illness (he has undergone two surgeries for a brain tumor and [[chemotherapy]] for [[Non-Hodgkin lymphoma|lymphoma]]). He has had public debates with [[Christopher Hitchens]], [[Sam Harris (author)|Sam Harris]], [[Steven Pinker]], [[Roger Cohen]], [[Richard Dawkins]], [[Matt Ridley]],<ref>[http://www.jewishjournal.com/videojew/item/live_video_tonight_a_dialogue_with_roger_cohen_and_the_iranian_jewish_commu/ "LIVE VIDEO TONIGHT: A Dialogue with Roger Cohen and the Iranian Jewish Community."]</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/16/opinion/16cohen.html?_r=1 | work=The New York Times | title=Iran, Jews and Pragmatism | first=Roger | last=Cohen | date=March 16, 2009 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=''[[The Huffington Post]]''|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rabbi-david-wolpe/clashing-over-iran-and-th_b_175326.html|title=Clashing Over Iran and the Jews|accessdate=May 11, 2009|date=March 16, 2009}}</ref> and Indian yogi and mystic [[Jaggi Vasudev|Sadhguru]], among others.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} Wolpe is the model for Jacob Kappelmacher, the rabbi detective in [[Jacob M. Appel|J. M. Appel's]] best-selling mystery novel, ''Wedding Wipeout'' (2012).<ref>''Encyclopedia of Jewish Fiction (rev. 2014), Pp. 34-5</ref>
Wolpe is the [[Max Webb]] Senior Rabbi of [[Sinai Temple (Los Angeles, California)|Sinai Temple]].<ref>David Suissa, [http://www.jewishjournal.com/david_suissa/article/max_webb_one_second_at_a_time Max Webb, one second at a time], ''[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles]]'', October 14, 2014</ref>
[[File:Elena Afshin Wedding.jpg|thumb|Wolpe officiating at a wedding in Los Angeles.]]
==Missions to Israel== Wolpe has led numerous missions to Israel. The first, in June 2002, was a solidarity mission at the height of the [[Second Intifada]] that broke out after the [[2000 Camp David Summit|Camp David peace talks]]. The second, in May 2005, was a mission of gratitude to pick up the [[Torah]] commissioned in honor of his recovery from brain surgery.<ref>http://www.jewishjournal.com/home/searchview.php?id=11757</ref> The third, in July 2006, at the height of the [[2006 Israel-Hezbollah War]], was another solidarity mission that covered [[Jerusalem]], [[Haifa]], and [[Sderot]]. In the midst of the second intifada, Wolpe raised three million dollars for victims of terror in a single morning at his [[synagogue]]. Wolpe also led the largest American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) delegation ever assembled from one synagogue to the AIPAC conference in Washington in 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, and 2012 with numbers ranging from 230-300 delegates. Wolpe also traveled to Haiti to help his friend [[Mitch Albom]] ''([[Tuesdays with Morrie]])'' rebuild an orphanage.<ref>http://www.jewishjournal.com/cover_story/article/christian_charity_in_haiti_is_the_jewish_thing_to_do_20110119/</ref>
==Historicity of the Exodus== {{Further|Historicity of the Bible}} On [[Passover]] 2001, Wolpe told his congregation that "the way the Bible describes the Exodus is not the way it happened, if it happened at all." Casting doubt on the historicity of [[the Exodus]] during the [[holiday]] that commemorates it brought condemnation from congregants and several rabbis (especially [[Orthodox Rabbi]]s). The ensuing theological debate included whole issues of Jewish newspapers such as the ''[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]'' in Los Angeles and editorials in ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', as well as an article in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Critics asserted that Wolpe was attacking Jewish [[oral history]], the significance of Passover and even the [[Ten Commandments|First Commandment]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} Wolpe asserted that he was arguing that the historicity of the events should not matter, since he believes [[faith]] is not determined by the same criteria as empirical [[truth]]. Wolpe argues that his views are based on the fact that no archeological digs have produced evidence of the Jews wandering the Sinai Desert for forty years, and that excavations in Israel consistently show settlement patterns at variance with the Biblical account of a sudden influx of Jews from Egypt.
In March 2010, Wolpe expounded on his views saying that it was possible that a small group of people left Egypt, came to Canaan, and influenced the native Canaanites with their traditions. He added that the controversy of 2001 stemmed from the fact that [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative Jewish]] congregations have been slow to accept and embrace [[biblical criticism]]. Conservative rabbis, on the other hand, are taught biblical criticism in rabbinical school.<ref>Q&A following [http://www.sinaitemple.org/programs/031710Dayan.mp3 a lecture on the Exodus] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129150509/http://sinaitemple.org/programs/031710Dayan.mp3 |date=2010-11-29 }} given at Sinai Temple, March 17, 2010. Begin listening at 00:58:53 until 01:02:31.</ref>
==Covenantal Judaism== On November 10, 2005, Rabbi Wolpe addressed the Jewish Theological Seminary and proposed that the name of Conservative Judaism be changed to "Covenantal Judaism," to better encompass the view that rabbinic law is both binding and evolving.
==Vegetarianism== Wolpe is a committed [[Vegetarianism|vegetarian]]. Rob Eshman suggests that Wolpe "leans [[Veganism|vegan]]."<ref>http://www.jewishjournal.com/foodaism/item/friday_the_rabbi_eats_tofu_20100305/</ref> Wolpe serves on the Rabbinic Council of Jewish Vegetarians of North America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishveg.com/content/about-us-20 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111190338/http://www.jewishveg.com/content/about-us-20 |archivedate=2013-11-11 |df= }}</ref>
==Bibliography== * ''[http://www.penguin.com/author/david-j-wolpe/231465 The Healer of Shattered Hearts: A Jewish View of God]'' (1991) {{ISBN|0-14-014795-0}} * ''In Speech and In Silence: The Jewish Quest for God'' (1992) {{ISBN|0-8050-2816-1}} * [http://harpercollins.com/books/9780060976477/Teaching_Your_Children_About_God/index.aspx ''Teaching your Children About God: A Modern Jewish Approach''] (1995) {{ISBN|0-06-097647-0}}. Wolpe believes that nurturing children spiritually leads to greater intellectual and emotional enlightenment. * ''[http://us.macmillan.com/books/9780805039276 Why be Jewish?]'' (1995) {{ISBN|0-8050-3927-9}} * ''[http://www.penguin.com/author/david-j-wolpe/231465 Making Loss Matter: Creating Meaning in Difficult Times]'' (1999) {{ISBN|1-57322-820-6}}. Wolpe recognizes the ultimate human potential to find strength from loss. He tells stories from his own life in addition to relaying lessons from ancient stories, rabbis, poets, philosophers, and scholars. * ''[http://www.behrmanhouse.com/store/product-sku/733 Floating Takes Faith: Ancient Wisdom for a Modern World]'' (2004) {{ISBN|0-87441-733-3}}. This collection of essays, explores some of the most challenging questions for the modern Jew. It considers how Jews live today and how ancient Jewish values shape the contemporary Jew’s understanding of his place in the modern world. * [http://www.harpercollins.com/books/Why-Faith-Matters-David-J-Wolpe?isbn=9780061633355&HCHP=TB_Why+Faith+Matters ''Why Faith Matters''] (2009) {{ISBN|0061633356}}, Rabbi Wolpe blends the powerful personal story of his struggles with his own faith with a poignant response to the new atheists that reveals just how important faith in modern society. * [http://yalebooks.com/book/9780300188783/david ''David: The Divided Heart''] (2014) {{ISBN|978-0300188783}}. Of all the figures in the Bible, David arguably stands out as the most perplexing and enigmatic. He was many things: a warrior who subdued Goliath and the Philistines; a king who united a nation; a poet who created beautiful, sensitive verse; a loyal servant of God who proposed the great Temple and founded the Messianic line; a schemer, deceiver, and adulterer who freely indulged his very human appetites.

L.Bolus }}
'''''Delosperma cooperi''''' ([[synonymy|syn.]] ''Mesembryanthemum cooperi''; common names '''Trailing Iceplant''', Hardy Iceplant, or "Pink Carpet") is a dwarf [[perennial plant]], native to [[South Africa]]. It forms a dense lawn with abundant, long-lasting flowering. It will reach sizes of approximately {{convert|10|–|15|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} tall, with fleshy leaves and a trailing stem that hangs down.
The flowers are the most brilliant aspect of this plant, with the production of a great quantity of vermillion, magenta or pink flowers that will often cover the entire site, hence the popular name "pink carpet". The plant contains ramified stems that are spread out, carrying sheets opposed, and are long and narrow, with the end of the stems increasing into a quantity of isolated small flowers, with diameters ranging from {{convert|3|to|5|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}}. These abundant and long-lasting flowers will remain in bloom from July through September.{{Where|date=May 2012}} The plant is sun-loving, and thrives well in very dry and hot environments. While it adapts well to various soil types, it will suffer under [[water stagnation]], and thus prefers well drained soils, or even rocky terrain.
According to the New Mexico State University extension, the common name, "ice plant" is because "they have bladder-like hairs on the leaf surface that reflect and refract light in a manner to make it appear that they sparkle like ice crystals" (or tiny glass beads). However, many other species of succulent so-called "ice plant" ground covers have smooth and hairless leaves.
==Cultivation and uses== It can be cultivated in a wide range of areas with a [[Mediterranean climate]]. Unlike many ice plants, this species is hardy to {{convert|-20|°F|°C|abbr=on}}, successfully overwintering at locations such as Denver, Colorado and Chicago, Illinois. The leaves turn red in cold winter temperatures. Due to the low need for maintenance, it is suitable for urban environments and high temperature regions. It can often be found in large, extensive patches. The trailing stems also make it suitable for flowerpots and terraces.
Propagation can be accomplished by taking a flowerless cutting, stripping a couple of bottom leaves off, and then replanting in the same soil.
The plant contains the halucinogen chemicals [[N,N-Dimethyltryptamine|DMT]] and [[5-MeO-DMT]], which can be extracted from the leaves. The content of these chemicals varies over the year. The content of 5-MeO-DMT rises during the summer and the content of DMT instead rises during the winter.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://troutsnotes.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/SoS_2004_Trout.pdf|title=Trout’s Notes on Some Other Succulents|journal=Sacred Cacti Third Edition}}</ref>

{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = Denkoroku | title_orig = | translator = Francis Dojun Cook (1991, 2003) | image = Denkoroku.jpg | image_caption = | author = [[Keizan]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Japan | language = [[English language|English]] from [[Japanese language|Japanese]] | series = | subject = | genre = [[Philosophy]]
[[Religion]] | publisher = | release_date = 1300 | english_release_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 0-86171-330-3 | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} {{ZenBuddhism}} {{Nihongo|'''''Denkōroku'''''|伝光録||''Record of the Transmission of the Light''}} is a [[kōan]] collection written in 1300 by [[Keizan]] Jokin Zenji, the Great Patriarch of [[Sōtō|Sōtō Zen]] [[Buddhism]], based on approximately a year of his [[Dharma talk]]s. The book includes 53 [[Enlightenment (spiritual)|enlightenment]] stories covering 1600 or more years based on the traditional legendary accounts of [[Dharma transmission]] in the Sōtō lineage. Successive masters and disciples in the book are [[Gautama Buddha|Shakyamuni Buddha]] circa 360 to 440 BCE in India, to Zen master [[Koun Ejō|Ejō]] in about 1230 or 1240 in Japan. While other translations are available as of 2012, this article was developed for the most part from the introduction and translator's note by Francis Dojun Cook. ==Synopsis== ===Contents=== Dharma transmissions covered 28 ancestors from [[India]] and 23 from [[China]], followed by [[Dōgen]] and Ejō in [[Japan]].[[John Daido Loori]], in Cook, pp. xi–xii. Out of modesty and his sense of propriety, Keizan, the 54th ancestor, omitted himself and [[Tettsu Gikai]], one of his teachers who was a student of Ejō and was still alive in 1300.Cook, p. 2. Each chapter is a few pages, except in a couple cases where the author wants to explain a point. The format for each koan account is in four parts: (1) the main koan case that is the enlightenment encounter between master and disciple, (2) a brief biographical account on the life of the disciple including context for the encounter, (3) Keizan's ''[[Buddhist_terms_and_concepts#T|teisho]]'' or commentary on the koan, and (4) a verse written by Keizan summarizing the point, following the Zen tradition of understanding presented by the master or disciple in [[poetry]].Loori, in Cook, pp. xiii–xiv. The book is not true in a strictly historical sense: for example, [[Bodhidharma]] is probably a mythical figure, the Sixth Patriarch was probably not [[Huineng]], and someone else probably wrote the ''[[Platform Sutra]]''.Cook, p. 15. Instead ''Denkōroku'' may be read as true in the sense that great novels like ''[[Moby-Dick]]'' or ''[[The Great Gatsby]]'' are true.Cook, p. 16. Keizan included fantastical or magical details from the lives of some ancestors, especially those in India, which audiences in times past may have appreciated but which today might be met with skepticism.Cook, p. 4. The following summary is taken from the Cook translation table of contents, with names according to [[Thomas Cleary]] in parentheses. ===India=== Keizan begins with [[Gautama Buddha|Shakyamuni]], the historical Buddha, followed by his disciple [[Mahākāśyapa|Mahākāśhyapa]] (Kasyapa), and then [[Ananda]], both of whom knew Buddha before he died.Cook, pp. 32, 36. Following are [[Shanavasa]], [[Upagupta]], Dhritaka (Dhrtaka), Micchaka, [[Vasumitra]], Buddhanandi, Buddhamitra (PunyamitraCleary, Contents pp. v-vii.), [[Parshva]], Punyayashas, [[Ashvaghosa]] (Ashvaghosha), and Kapimala. Then comes [[Nagarjuna]], [[Kanadeva]], Rahulata, Sanghanandi, Gayashata (Jayashata), Kumarata, Jayata, [[Vasubandhu]], Manorhita (Manora), Haklenayashas (Haklena), Aryasimha (Sinha), Basiasita (Vashashita), Punyamitra, and [[Prajnatara]]. Finally, [[Bodhidharma]] was the 28th ancestor from India.Cook, p. 147. Cook, Contents pp. vii-ix. ===China=== Following Bodhidharma, [[Dazu Huike]] (Huike [Shenguang]) was the 29th ancestor, the 2nd in China.Cook, p. 153. Following are [[Jianzhi Sengcan]] (Sengcan), [[Dayi Daoxin]] (Daoxin), [[Daman Hongren]] (Hongren), [[Huineng|Dajian Huineng]] (Huineng), [[Qingyuan Xingsi]] (Qingyuan), [[Shitou Xiqian]] (Shitou), [[Yaoshan Weiyan]] (Yaoshan), [[Yunyan Tansheng]] (Yunyan), [[Dongshan Liangjie]] (Dongshan), Yunhju Daoying (Yunju), [[Tongan Daopi]] (Daopi), [[Tongan Guanzhi]] (Tongan), [[Liangshan Yuanguan]] (Liangshan), [[Dayang Jingxuan]] (Dayang), [[Touzi Yiqing]] (Touzi), [[Furong Daokai]] (Daokai), [[Danxia Zichun]] (Danxia), [[Zhenxie Qingliao]] (Wukong), [[Tiantong Zongjue]] (Zongjue), Xuedou Zhijian (Zhijian), and [[Rujing|Tiantong Rujing]] (Rujing). ===Japan=== The 51st ancestor was [[Dōgen|Eihei Dogen]] who traveled from Japan to China and back.Cook, pp. 255, 258, 261. The 52nd ancestor was his student, [[Koun Ejō]].Cook, p. 266. ==Authorship== [[File:Keizan-SotoZen-Net.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Waist high view of man with shaved head|[[Keizan]] is generally held to be the author.]] Keizan originally gave this series of 53 Dharma talks to the monks of the [[Daijō-ji]] monastery during spring and the following winter ''[[ango]]'' practice periods. Keizan was 36 years old at the time. According to one translator, Francis Cook, there is some controversy and "uneasiness" about authorship.Cook, p. 24. At first, the work was hidden from the public eye for nearly 600 years. A monk named Sen'ei was the first to publish it, in 1857, or 557 years after it was written.Cook, p. 23. Then in 1886, Yoshida Gizan published an annotated edition in Kyoto. In 1885, [[Sōji-ji]] published what is called the Honzan edition, based on a manuscript copy owned by a private collector. The oldest existing manuscript copy was found in 1959. It is thought to have been copied during the late to mid-15th century. [[Komazawa University]] published a catalog in 1962, which listed 11 copies. By 1976, 19 copies were known—some of them verified and some not. Some of these copies were known to no longer exist. Okubo Doshu, a noted Dogen scholar, doubted the work's author for a number of reasons, including discrepancies in the last two chapters, along with the absence of a historical record attributing what is a major work to Keizan. But neither he nor any other scholar has ever come out to say that Keizan is ''not'' the author, so the consensus remains to attribute the work to Keizan.Cook, pp. 24–25. ==Author== While [[Dōgen]] is held to be the school's founder, Keizan was in large part responsible for the flourishing of Sōtō Zen. He resisted the purist approach taken by Dōgen who preferred to teach and write; he took care to serve his congregation who might have dead or dying relatives; he founded new monasteries and temples; and he attracted followers like Gashau and Meiho who became his successors.Cook, p. 22. Today Sōtō Zen remains one of the largest Buddhist organizations in Japan. ==Reaction== One translator, Cleary, writes: {{quote|One of the proverbial guidelines for Zen study is: "First awaken on your own, then see someone else." As a handbook of method, ''Transmission of Light'' is a classic guide to "awakening on your own." As a collection of criteria, it is a way to "see someone else."Cleary, p. xxi.}} ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== * Roshi P. T. N. Jiyu Kennett, ''Zen is Eternal Life'', Shasta Abbey Press, 4th edition, 2000, {{ISBN|0-930066-20-0}} * ''[http://www.shastaabbey.org/teachings-publications_denkoroku.html The Denkoroku: or The Record of the Transmission of the Light]'', by Keizan Zenji, translated by Rev. Hubert Nearman, Shasta Abbey Press, 2001, {{ISBN|0-930066-22-7}} * ''Transmission of Light, Zen in the Art of Enlightenment by Zen Master Keizan'', Translated and introduction by Thomas Cleary, North Point Press, San Francisco, 1990. {{ISBN|0-86547-433-8}} * ''The Record of Transmitting the Light: Zen Master Keizan's Denkoroku'', Translated and introduction by Francis Dojun Cook, Wisdom Publications, 2003 [1991], {{ISBN|0-86171-330-3}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Denkoroku}} [[Category:Zen texts]] [[Category:14th-century books]] [[Category:Spiritual practice]] [[Category:Zen koan collections]] [[Category:1300 in Asia]] [[Category:14th century in Japan]]

The '''districts of the Church of the Brethren''' are 23 regional divisions that serve to administer the 1,035 congregations<ref name="list">{{Cite web|url=http://www.brethren.org/site/PageServer?pagename=cob_dirSearch&searchChurch=&searchDistrict=&searchCity=&searchState=PR&searchZip=&dir_search=Search |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110811151912/http://www.brethren.org/site/PageServer?pagename=cob_dirSearch&searchChurch=&searchDistrict=&searchCity=&searchState=PR&searchZip=&dir_search=Search |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-08-11 |title=Church directory |publisher=Church of the Brethren |accessdate=2010-04-21 }}</ref> of the [[Church of the Brethren]] in the [[United States]] and [[Puerto Rico]]. Districts are divided along state and county lines with membership and geographic scope varying widely. The Church of the Brethren is present in 34 states, Puerto Rico, and [[Washington, D. C.]] in addition to their overseas missions.
==History and purpose== The district system has existed amongst [[Schwarzenau Brethren]] since 1856—prior to the 1881–1883 split—and served the administrative purpose of determining delegates to the Annual Conference who could represent the interests of various communities and report back to them the proceedings.<ref name="vine">{{Citation |last=Durnbaugh |first=Donald F. |title=Fruit of the Vine: A History of the Brethren 1708–1995 |format=Hardback |year=1997 |publisher=[[Brethren Press]] |location=[[Elgin, Illinois|Elgin]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]] |isbn=0-87178-003-8 |page=219}}</ref> The Church of the Brethren is governed by a [[Congregationalist polity|Congregationalist]] model of church polity, so most decisions are made locally by individual congregations without interference from any hierarchical structure. Delegates from districts serve the purpose of raising issues at Annual Conferences (called "queries") which affect the Church of the Brethren at large or which have a scope greater than that of a single congregation or locality—e.g. the [[ordination of women]] or how to regulate funds for [[Missionary|missions activities]]. Due to the increase in queries presented to the Annual Conference, in 1856, the Brethren approved the establishment of districts of no less than five churches that would answer queries that had a local scope.<ref name="dev103">*{{Citation |last=Stoffer |first=Dale R. |editor=William R. Eberly |title=Background and Development of Brethren Doctrines 1650–1987 |format=Hardback |edition=1st |series=Brethren Encyclopedia Monograph Series |volume=2 |year=1989 |publisher=Brethren Encyclopedia, Inc. |location=[[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] |isbn=0-936693-22-3 |page=103}}</ref>

==Churches outside the United States== [[File:Church of the Brethren map.svg|alt=A line-drawing of a world map with the United States and Puerto Rico in black; Ecuador and India in violet; Brazil, the Dominican Republic, Haiti, Nigeria, and Sudan in cyan; and Argentina, mainland China, Denmark, France, Indonesia, Niger, Sweden, Switzerland, and Turkey in magenta.|400px|thumb|A map of the worldwide scope of the Church of the Brethren: {{legend|black|Headquarters of the Church (United States and Puerto Rico)}} {{legend|skyblue|Current overseas missions (Brazil; the Dominican Republic; Haiti; Nigeria and Oku, Cameroon; and Southern Sudan)}} {{legend|purple|Churches that are the result of mergers with other Protestant missions (Ecuador's United Andean Indian Mission and the Church of North India; a single Indian church still belongs to the Church of the Brethren)}} {{legend|magenta|Foreign missions that have closed (Argentina, China, Denmark and Sweden, France and Switzerland, Indonesia, Niger, and Turkey)}}]] The Church of the Brethren began missionary activities in the late 19th century, which included the establishment of churches in Africa, the Americas, Asia, and Europe.
